The soil in the container looks uniformly dark and clumped, indicating persistent wetness; the crown area is brown-black and slightly sunken; several leaflets are limp, shriveled and silver-brown at the edges; and the stolon is thin with little active root growth, all signaling oxygen-starved roots beginning to rot. These visual cues point to continual saturation and poor drainage depriving roots of air and triggering crown/root rot. Allow the upper 2.5 cm (1 in) of soil to dry completely, then irrigate only 200 ml (≈7 fl oz) every 3–4 days or when that layer is dry; gently fork and blend the top 3 cm (1¼ in) of mix with about 25 % coarse perlite to open air channels; and raise the pot on 2 cm (¾ in) spacers to let excess water drain and airflow reach the base. Over the next week, visually confirm that the surface feels dry before each watering, check the crown daily for firmness and a light tan (not dark) color, and watch for the appearance of new turgid green leaflets as an early sign of recovery.

Diagnosis: overwatered. Multiple leaves are limp, brown, and papery while still attached to floppy, prostrate petioles, the soil surface is uniformly dark and glossy-wet, and the remaining green leaflet shows pale chlorosis and slight edge curling, all pointing to excess moisture suffocating roots. These symptoms indicate saturated substrate and poor aeration that are depriving the crown and fine roots of oxygen, leading to tissue collapse. Immediately allow the container to drain fully, then withhold irrigation until the top 2–3 cm (≈1 in) of soil feels dry to the touch; thereafter give no more than 200 ml (≈¾ cup) of water per plant every 3–4 days, delivered slowly so it penetrates about 10 cm (4 in) deep. Elevate the fabric pot on two small slats to create a 1 cm air gap under it and gently mix 1 part coarse perlite into the top 5 cm (2 in) of soil to improve airflow. For the next week, check daily that the soil surface lightens in color within 24 h after watering, inspect the crown for firm, white tissue instead of mushy brown, and look for upright, turgid new leaflets emerging from the center as confirmation the root zone is recovering.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The soil surface is uniformly dark and glistening, suggesting continual saturation; fine cracks show only in the upper crust, not deeper, indicating poor percolation. Stems are limp and laying flat with a translucent, water-soaked look, while leaves are grey-green, shriveled, and fringed with fuzzy mold—classic signs of tissue collapse from excess moisture. Several petioles show brown rot at their bases, and no healthy white roots or new growth are visible, confirming root suffocation. The likely cause is prolonged watering without adequate drainage, creating anaerobic conditions that allowed opportunistic fungi to colonize foliage and crowns. Immediately tip the pot to drain any standing water, then let the top 3 cm (1¼ in) of mix dry before the next irrigation; afterwards, water only 250 ml (about 1 cup) every 4–5 days, or when the top 3 cm feel dry. Repot into a mix amended with 30 % perlite and ensure at least three 1 cm (⅜ in) diameter drainage holes; remove all dead foliage and space pots so air can circulate on all sides. Over the next 7 days, check daily that the upper 3 cm of soil is dry to the touch, lift the pot to confirm it feels lighter before each watering, and watch for emergence of firm, pale new leaves without further grey mold on the surface.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The visible soil is dark, glossy, and clumped, indicating persistent saturation; the crown and petiole bases are coated in fuzzy white mycelium; leaves are limp, yellow-brown, and shriveled; the main stem appears thin, water-softened, and partially collapsed; and there is no evidence of fresh white feeder roots at the surface. These clues point to waterlogging that has suffocated roots and encouraged opportunistic fungi. Immediately tip the pot to drain excess water, then allow the top 3 cm (1¼ in) of mix to dry completely before the next irrigation; when watering after that, apply roughly 200 ml (7 fl oz) evenly until moisture reaches 5 cm (2 in) depth, no more than once every 4–5 days. Repot into a container with at least three 1 cm (⅜ in) drainage holes and mix in 25 % coarse perlite to improve aeration, trimming off any mushy roots and removing all moldy leaf debris. Place the pot where it receives gentle airflow and bright indirect light, and spread a 1 cm (⅜ in) layer of clean straw mulch once surface dryness is reliable to prevent future splashing. Over the next seven days, daily check that the upper 3 cm of soil feels dry before re-watering, inspect the crown for new firm green growth rather than brown mush, and look for any return of white mold on the surface or stem; if mold reappears, gently scrape it off and increase airflow by spacing plants at least 15 cm (6 in) apart.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The foliage is limp and flattened against the soil, leaf blades show a dull grey-green hue with curled edges, and the petioles appear soft and weak rather than upright; the potting mix looks uniformly dark, dense and matted, with small patches of whitish organic growth and no visible dry, crumbly zones, all suggesting prolonged saturation. These visual cues indicate that roots have been deprived of oxygen, leading to water-stress wilt even though moisture is abundant. Allow the top 2–3 cm (about one inch) of soil to dry completely before the next irrigation and then supply no more than 200 ml (≈7 fl oz) of water, letting excess drain freely; tilt or raise the container 2 cm off the tray so drainage holes stay clear; at the next repot, blend the mix with 30 % coarse perlite or pine bark to improve airflow. Over the coming week: 1) press a finger to 2 cm depth daily and water only when it feels powdery rather than cool, 2) watch for newly emerging leaves that stand upright within 3–5 days, and 3) inspect the soil surface each morning for any new white fungal film or sour odor, a sign conditions are still too wet.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The soil appears uniformly dark, glossy, and compacted, indicating persistent saturation rather than a crumbly, aerated texture. Both visible leaves are limp, dull, and grey-green, with edges curling downward and a felted surface that suggests loss of turgor. A fine orange-brown biofilm and patches of fuzzy organic residue are scattered across the soil surface, a typical by-product of excess moisture encouraging microbial growth. These clues together point to oxygen-starved roots and early rot triggered by chronic over-irrigation. Immediately reduce watering to no more than 250 ml every 5–6 days, and only after the upper 4–5 cm (1.5–2 in) of soil is completely dry; elevate the pot 2 cm on spacers and add a 1 cm layer of coarse mulch to improve drainage and surface aeration. Increase airflow by positioning a fan to move air gently across the foliage for 4 hours each morning and thin any dense nearby plants to create at least 10 cm of open space around the crown. Over the next 7 days, check that the top soil layer lightens in color and turns crumbly, confirm new leaf petioles stand upright within 48 hours of each irrigation, and sniff the crown daily for any sour or sulfurous odor that would signal ongoing root rot.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The potting mix appears almost black and glossy, indicating saturation, and large fissures show it has compacted after repeated wetting; several stems are limp and tan, with leaves shriveled and grey-green instead of vibrant, while patches of white fuzzy mold sit on the soil surface and dead tissue. These visual clues collectively point to prolonged excess moisture that suffocated roots, encouraged fungal growth, and prevented nutrient uptake. Immediately allow the top 2–3 cm (≈1 in) of the mix to dry completely before giving any water, then limit irrigation to roughly 250 mL (≈1 cup) every 4–5 days or only when that upper layer is dry. Improve drainage by mixing in about 20 % coarse perlite at the next repotting and drilling four or five extra 0.5 cm (¼ in) holes in the pot base to increase outflow and airflow. Remove the visible moldy debris and top-dress with a 1 cm (⅜ in) layer of coarse sand or fine bark to deter surface fungi and splash. Over the next week, daily check moisture by inserting a finger 3 cm deep; the soil should feel barely moist before re-watering. Inspect the crown for any fresh, firm green shoots and ensure remaining leaves regain turgor instead of staying floppy. Also look for new white mold patches or a sour smell each morning, which would signal lingering excess moisture requiring longer drying intervals.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The wilted, grey-green leaves are lying flat against the soil, the stems appear limp and slightly darkened, the potting mix is uniformly dark and glossy as if waterlogged, and wide fissures have formed where saturated soil later shrank and compacted, all indicating chronic excess moisture and poor aeration. Prolonged saturation has likely suffocated fine roots and promoted decay, leaving the tops unable to stay turgid. Remove each plant, trim any blackened roots, and re-pot into a fresh mix amended with 30 % coarse perlite or pine bark, filling the container to at least 15 cm (6 in) depth and ensuring the drainage holes remain unobstructed. Thereafter irrigate only when the upper 2.5 cm (1 in) of mix feels dry, applying about 250 ml (1 cup) per plant slowly so water penetrates 10 cm (4 in) deep, then allow full drainage. Elevate the pot on spacers or a mesh stand to improve airflow beneath and keep the crown just above the soil surface. Over the next seven days, visually confirm that the top 2 cm of mix lightens in color between waterings, check daily for any new pale green leaf buds emerging at the crown, and sniff the soil for any sour or rotten odor—persistence of moisture gloss or foul smell signals the need for further drainage correction.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The potting mix appears uniformly dark and glossy, indicating saturation, and it is broken into heavy, compacted clumps rather than loose crumbs. Several leaves are limp, pale, and curling with browned edges, a classic sign of root suffocation rather than nutrient burn. Thin, elongated runners lie flat and lifeless on the surface instead of standing firm, suggesting roots are failing to support growth. An active drip emitter sits only a few centimetres from the crown, hinting at frequent localized soakings. No fresh white feeder roots are visible at the soil surface, implying root rot may already be advancing. These clues together point to excess water cutting off oxygen and weakening the plant. Immediately cut irrigation to a single 250 ml application every 3–4 days, delivered only after the top 2 cm (¾ in) of soil feels dry; raise the fabric pot on a 2 cm (¾ in) slatted rack to improve drainage and underside airflow; and gently mix 1 cm (⅜ in) of coarse perlite into the top layer to speed evaporation. Over the next week, check daily that the soil surface lightens in colour and feels dry to the first knuckle, lift the pot to ensure its weight drops noticeably before each watering, and watch for any new upright green leaflets emerging as confirmation that roots are recovering.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The potting mix appears almost black and glossy, indicating continual saturation; its surface is compacted into large, wet clods with no visible dry granules; several leaves are limp and laying flat on the soil rather than held upright; leaf tissue shows pale yellow-grey patches and marginal browning; and the central crown looks shrunken and discolored. These clues point to excess moisture depriving roots of oxygen, leading to loss of turgor and early crown rot. Allow the top 3 cm (≈1¼ in) of soil to dry completely before the next watering, then irrigate slowly until only 10–15 % of the water volume drains from the bottom, roughly 250 ml for this fabric pot; elevate the container on a slatted stand to improve airflow beneath and around the root zone; and gently rake the crusted surface to 1 cm depth to break it up and enhance evaporation. Over the next week, visually confirm that the top layer lightens in color within 48 h of watering, check daily that leaves regain firmness in the morning, and sniff the media every other day for any sour or sulfur odor that would signal persisting waterlogging.

Diagnosis: overwatered. Several clues support this: the potting mix appears uniformly dark and glistening, indicating water saturation; the soil surface is sunken and compacted with no dry crust, a sign of prolonged moisture; the central crown looks brown-orange and mushy rather than firm; multiple leaflets are limp, grey-green or yellowing at the edges, and lying flat instead of standing upright; and fine roots are exposed and desiccated, suggesting rot below. These symptoms point to excess irrigation that has deprived roots of oxygen and initiated decay. Immediately withhold watering until the top 3 cm (≈1¼ in) of soil feels dry to the touch, then resume at only 200 ml (≈7 fl oz) per plant every 3–4 days, ensuring water is delivered slowly around the drip line rather than directly at the crown. Elevate the fabric pot on slats to improve drainage and gently loosen the top 2 cm of soil with a clean fork to enhance airflow. Over the next week, monitor daily for: a) the soil’s color returning to a lighter brown on the surface, b) emergence of firm, upright new leaves at least 2 cm long, and c) absence of further crown softening or foul odor when lightly pressed. If any foul smell or continued leaf collapse is observed, extend the dry interval by another 48 hours before the next light watering.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The soil surface appears uniformly dark and glossy, indicating saturation, while the potting mix is compacted and lacks the light, crumbly texture of aerated media. Petioles are limp and sprawled flat against the soil, and several leaves display a dull grey-green to yellow cast rather than vibrant green, suggesting chronic oxygen deprivation. Fine white fungal threads are visible around the crown and along petioles, pointing to excess moisture fostering opportunistic fungi. The crown shows an orange-brown soft spot, consistent with early rot that follows prolonged waterlogging. Reduce irrigation to no more than 250 ml per watering and only when the top 3 cm (1¼ in) of soil feels dry; aim for a watering depth of 4 cm (1½ in) rather than soaking the entire pot. Elevate the fabric pot on a slatted stand to improve drainage, and gently mix 20 % coarse perlite or pine bark into the top 5 cm (2 in) of soil to restore porosity. Remove all wilted foliage at the base with sterilised scissors and keep the crown slightly above the soil line to enhance airflow. Over the next seven days, press a finger 3 cm into the mix each morning and water only when it feels barely moist, observe the soil color turning from black-wet to medium brown within 24 h after watering, and inspect the crown daily for firmness and absence of new white fungal threads or orange ooze.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The soil surface is uniformly dark and glossy, indicating saturation; a drip emitter is positioned close to the crown, implying frequent watering; the petioles are limp and sprawled on the medium; lower leaves show brown, papery decay; and a grey-white fungal film is visible on the crown area. These visual cues point to oxygen-poor conditions and early root rot caused by excessive, poorly drained moisture. Suspend watering for 48 h, then resume with 250 ml per plant every 3 days, aiming to moisten only the upper 5 cm while allowing the top 3 cm to dry between cycles; set the container on 2 cm spacers and work 20 % coarse perlite into the top 4 cm of mix for faster drainage; and remove all dead, mold-covered leaves with alcohol-sterilized scissors to reduce inoculum. Add a 2 cm straw mulch ring that does not touch the crown to buffer surface moisture without trapping it. Over the next week, test soil daily by inserting a finger 3 cm deep—water only when it feels dry. Lift the pot at each check to learn its “light when dry” weight as a second guide. Inspect the crown every morning for fresh, turgid leaves, any new grey mold growth, or a sour odor, and note improvements or setbacks.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The potting mix appears almost black and glossy, indicating constant saturation; tan fungal mats are scattered on the surface; a limp drip-line suggests continuous irrigation; the seedling leaves are pale yellow-green, curled and lying flat on the soil; and lower stems look dark and weak. These visual cues point to oxygen-starved roots and secondary surface fungi caused by excessive, frequent watering. Allow the upper 3–4 cm (1½ in) of soil to dry before the next irrigation, then supply only 250 ml (about 1 cup) every 3–4 days, adjusting so water penetrates 10 cm (4 in) deep but never pools; elevate or add two 0.5 cm (¼ in) drainage holes to the fabric pot’s base; and top-dress with a 2 cm (¾ in) layer of coarse bark to moderate evaporation without trapping moisture. Increase airflow by spacing the pot at least 10 cm (4 in) from walls and clearing any surrounding clutter. Over the next 7 days, check that the soil surface lightens in color and feels only slightly cool, observe whether new leaves stand upright by morning, and verify that the tan fungal patches recede rather than spread; if any area still looks shiny or smells sour, extend the dry interval by another day before watering again.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The potting mix appears uniformly dark and glossy, indicating continual saturation; small pools of moisture cling to the coarse particles near the crown; several leaves are limp, yellow-brown and curling downward; the central crown shows mushy, grayish fuzz suggestive of water-favored decay; and stems lie flat against the soil instead of standing erect. These clues point to excess irrigation combined with poor aeration in the fabric pot. Allow the top 3 cm (≈1.25 in) of soil to dry before the next watering and then give no more than 250 ml (≈1 cup) every 3–4 days, applying slowly so only the upper 8 cm (≈3 in) is moistened; raise the pot on a 2 cm (¾ in) slatted rack to improve drainage airflow underneath; and clip off all wilted or moldy tissue, disposing of it away from the bed to reduce inoculum. Over the next seven days, check each morning by inserting a finger 2 cm into the mix—delay watering if it feels cool or sticks to the skin; observe the crown for any fresh gray fuzz or softening; and watch the newest leaves for a return of upright posture and light green color, which signals recovery.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The potting mix appears uniformly dark and glossy, indicating persistent saturation; white fuzzy filaments lie across the surface, showing fungi favored by excess moisture; several older leaves are limp, grey-brown and papery, suggesting root suffocation; the few surviving green leaves display small marginal lesions and slight chlorosis, hinting at disrupted nutrient uptake; and the fabric pot wall is damp-stained halfway up, proving water is being held instead of draining quickly. These clues together point to watering before the top 2–3 cm of medium could dry, depriving roots of oxygen and encouraging surface fungi. First, pause irrigation until the top 3 cm (about 1¼ in) feels dry, then resume with only 200 ml per watering, applied every 3–4 days or when that depth dries, ensuring brief runoff. Second, set the pot on a 2 cm slatted rack or bricks to promote airflow beneath and speed drainage. Third, lightly rake the upper 1 cm of soil and blend in a 1 cm layer of coarse perlite to improve porosity without disturbing roots. Over the next seven days, press a fingertip 2 cm into the soil each morning to confirm it is merely cool, not wet; inspect the soil surface for shrinkage of the white fungal mat; and watch new leaflets for restored firmness and absence of fresh brown spotting, adjusting the watering interval if any sign persists.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The soil surface is uniformly dark and glossy, suggesting constant saturation; the substrate is compacted in large, sticky clods with no visible aeration pockets; leaves are limp, downward-curling and blotchy yellow-green with darkened veins; petioles show brown, mushy bases; and several dried, greyish leaf remnants cling to the crown, indicating past rot. These visual clues point to prolonged excess moisture that has starved the roots of oxygen and initiated crown decay. Immediately allow the top 3 cm (1¼ in) of soil to dry before the next irrigation, then resume watering only when that layer feels dry, applying 250 ml (about 1 cup) per plant and letting it percolate fully through the drainage holes. Elevate the fabric pot on 2 cm (¾ in) spacers to improve airflow beneath, and gently mix 20 % perlite into the top 5 cm (2 in) of medium to increase porosity; finally, add a 1 cm (⅜ in) layer of coarse straw mulch to reduce surface crusting while still breathing. Over the next seven days, (1) press a finger 2 cm into the soil each morning to confirm that it stays only slightly damp, (2) watch for any new firm, upright leaflets emerging from the crown, and (3) inspect the crown base daily for a shift from brown-mushy to firm light-tan tissue and the absence of a sour smell.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The soil surface appears uniformly dark and slick, suggesting saturation; several lower leaves are limp, papery, and grey-white, indicating collapse from water-logged roots; a fuzzy white mycelial growth skirts the crown, a common sign of excess moisture fostering fungus; viable leaves show slight marginal yellowing and downward curl, hinting at oxygen deprivation; and the potting mix is compacted with no visible dry granules, confirming poor drainage. These clues collectively point to prolonged watering that has suffocated roots and invited opportunistic fungi. Immediately allow the top 2.5 cm (1 in) of soil to dry before the next irrigation, then resume watering only 200–250 ml every 4–5 days, ensuring water drains freely from the pot’s base; gently loosen the top 1 cm (½ in) of soil and mix in 20 % coarse perlite to improve aeration; finally, elevate the container on spacers to enhance airflow beneath and keep foliage dry. Over the next 7 days, visually verify that the soil surface lightens in color within 48 h of watering, confirm that new growth emerges firm and green rather than grey or limp, and check daily that the white fungal patches shrink or disappear instead of spreading.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The soil appears uniformly dark and smeared, indicating high moisture retention; several lower leaves are tan-brown, crisp, and lying flat, signalling root-related wilt; petioles are thin and flaccid rather than upright; stolons show yellowing; and only one small green leaflet remains, confirming general stress. These visual cues point to excess water depriving roots of oxygen and initiating rot. First, stop watering until the top 3 cm (about 1 in) of soil feels dry, then resume with 200–250 ml (roughly ½ cup) per plant every 3–4 days, applied early morning; second, improve drainage by raising the container on 2 cm spacers and adding four 5 mm holes around the lower sidewalls; third, lightly loosen the top 1 cm of soil to boost airflow and cover with a 0.5 cm layer of coarse composted mulch to moderate surface moisture. Over the next 7 days, daily verify dryness of the upper 3 cm by finger test before any watering, watch midday leaf stance for renewed firmness, and sniff the crown area for any sour or rotting odor that would indicate persistent saturation.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The growing medium is overly dark and clumped, indicating persistent moisture, and there is no lighter, friable texture typical of aerated soil. Several leaves are curled, papery, and bleached to tan, while others show yellow-green patches bordered by brown necrosis. The petioles lie flat and possess a translucent brown zone near the crown, and the crown itself appears sunken rather than firm. Together these clues point to chronic water saturation that has suffocated roots and initiated crown rot. Allow the upper 3 cm (≈1¼ in) of soil to dry before watering, then supply no more than 1 cm (≈⅜ in) of water every 4 days, letting excess drip completely through the container. Loosen the top 2 cm of mix and incorporate a 2 cm (≈¾ in) layer of coarse compost or perlite for better drainage, elevate the pot on 2 cm blocks, and remove the dead foliage with disinfected scissors. Over the next 7 days, check daily that the soil surface lightens to gray and feels dry at 2 cm depth, inspect the crown for firm white tissue instead of brown mush, and watch for any new crisp green leaflets standing upright.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The potting mix appears almost black and glossy, indicating saturation, and it shows deep vertical cracking that forms when a once-waterlogged medium begins to shrink; several stolons and petioles lie limp across the surface, and most attached leaves are papery-brown or translucent beige instead of firm green; only a single small leaflet retains color but its edges are slightly chlorotic. These clues point to prolonged excess moisture that has displaced air, suffocating roots and triggering leaf die-off. Allow the upper 3 cm (1¼ in) of soil to dry completely before the next irrigation, then apply no more than 350 ml (about 12 fl oz) every 3 days, watering slowly until you see the first drops exit the fabric pot; elevate the container 2 cm (¾ in) on slats to improve drainage and consider mixing in 1 cm (½ in) of coarse pine bark on the surface to reduce compaction and enhance airflow. Over the next week, gently fluff the top 1 cm of soil with a fork to break the crust, and move the plant where it receives light morning sun and a light breeze to hasten drying. Check daily whether the surface is dry to your first knuckle, sniff for any sour odor that would signal ongoing rot, and watch for emergence of firm, upright new leaves—green recovery and absence of new browning will confirm improvement. If wilting persists despite the dryer regime, inspect roots for mushiness before the next watering to decide on repotting into fresh, looser medium.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The potting mix is dark, shiny and clumpy with no loose crumb structure, suggesting sustained saturation; broad cracks run through the surface indicating the soil contracted after heavy wetting; the crown and petiole bases show brown-black collapse consistent with rot; remaining leaves are wilted, pale and curling downward; a faint white fungal film is visible on the dead foliage. These clues point to excess water stagnating around the roots, depriving them of oxygen and allowing crown-rot organisms to proliferate. Lift the fabric pot on two 3 cm wooden slats for better drainage, then irrigate only when the top 2.5 cm (1 in) of soil is dry, giving roughly 200 ml per watering rather than daily soaking; gently mix 1 part coarse perlite into the top 5 cm (2 in) of soil to improve aeration; remove the mushy plant tissue with sanitized scissors and discard away from the bed. Over the next week, (1) probe the soil daily to 2.5 cm depth to confirm it feels barely moist, not wet; (2) look for any new firm green buds emerging from the crown as a sign of recovery; (3) inspect the crown area each morning for further browning or white fungal growth and repeat tissue removal if it reappears.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The lower leaflet is uniformly yellow with a few brown speckles while veins stay faintly green, upper leaf margins curl downward, petioles droop, and the soil surface appears grey, crusted and split, all indicating roots that have sat in water and then dried into a hard pan. These combined visual cues signal oxygen deprivation and nutrient lock-out caused by frequent heavy watering in a poorly draining medium. Allow the top 2.5 cm (1 in) of soil to dry before the next irrigation, then supply only about 120 ml (4 oz) evenly around the crown every 3–4 days, stopping as soon as you see the first drip from the base. Repot within 48 h into a 15 cm (6 in) pot containing a fresh mix of 60 % peat or coco, 30 % perlite and 10 % compost, and elevate the container on a slatted tray to improve airflow and drainage. Add a 1 cm (0.4 in) layer of straw or pine-needle mulch to prevent surface crusting without trapping excess moisture. For the next seven days, check soil moisture by inserting a finger 2 cm deep—it should feel only lightly damp, observe new leaves for firm posture and solid green color, and inspect the saucer twice daily to confirm no water is standing beneath the pot.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The potting mix appears almost black and sticky, indicating constant saturation, while several petioles lie limp and collapsed across the soil surface, and the shriveled leaves are edged with a pale gray fuzz suggestive of excess-moisture mold; additionally, scattered tan patches of fungal growth sit on top of the medium, and no firm, green crowns are visible. These clues point to prolonged waterlogging that deprived roots of oxygen, encouraged opportunistic fungi, and led to rapid crown decline. Immediately allow the container to drain fully and withhold irrigation until the top 5 cm (2 in) of mix is completely dry, then resume watering only 400–500 ml every 3–4 days or when the pot feels light. Improve drainage by mixing 30 % coarse perlite or pine bark into the upper 10 cm (4 in) of soil and elevating the fabric pot on a 2 cm (¾ in) slatted stand to boost airflow beneath it. Remove and discard the visibly rotted leaves and any loose moldy debris, and keep the foliage area clear for at least 15 cm (6 in) around the crowns to speed surface drying. Over the next seven days, check soil moisture daily by inserting a finger to 5 cm depth and watering only if it feels dry, inspect the crown base for firm, white tissue rather than brown mush, and watch for any new green leaf emergence or a reduction of surface mold as confirmation that the root zone is recovering.

Diagnosis: overwatered. I observe a thick gray-green fuzzy coating on several berries, water-soaked translucent patches on their skin, collapsed fruit tissue that looks mushy, and tight clustering of leaves and fruits that traps humidity. These clues point to prolonged surface moisture and stagnant air, conditions typical of excessive watering that favors Botrytis gray mold. Reduce irrigation to a single deep soak of about 2.5 cm (1 in) once every 5–7 days, applied at soil level early in the morning, and ensure runoff drains within 15 minutes; avoid wetting foliage or fruit. Gently remove and discard all visibly molded berries, then place a 3 cm (1¼ in) layer of clean straw under remaining clusters to keep fruit off damp soil and improve airflow by trimming crowded leaves so adjacent crowns stand at least 15 cm (6 in) apart. Over the next week, press your finger 5 cm (2 in) into the soil daily to confirm it is only slightly moist, inspect fruit surfaces each morning for new gray fuzz or darkening spots, and check under the straw for any standing water after irrigation or rain.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The foliage is wilted and laying flat rather than held upright, several leaves show uniform papery browning starting at the mid-rib, and others are a dull yellow-green with soft, water-soaked edges; the crown appears slightly darkened and the potting mix looks glossy and saturated with no dry crust. Such widespread limpness in the presence of visibly wet media points to root oxygen deprivation from excess moisture rather than drought. Allow the top 2.5 cm (about 1 in) of mix to dry before the next irrigation, then give only 120–150 ml (4–5 fl oz) of water, letting it drain completely; elevate the pot on a mesh or stones so the drainage holes stay clear, and aim for watering every 3–4 days rather than daily unless the surface dries sooner. Improve airflow by spacing pots at least 5 cm (2 in) apart and running a fan on low for 6 h each day; if available, add a 1 cm (½ in) layer of coarse bark mulch to limit surface algae and promote evaporation. Over the next week, check each morning that the top layer feels dry and crumbly, watch for new leaves emerging firm and upright, and inspect the pot base for any standing water or sour odor that would signal lingering saturation. If leaves regain turgor and new growth is healthy green, continue the adjusted schedule; if lower leaves remain mushy or crown darkens, withhold water another day and reassess drainage conditions.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The leaf is lying flat and limp, its petiole bending downward instead of holding the blade upright, and the surface shows a dark water-soaked streak along the midrib plus mushy brown patches near the margin; additionally, the tissue looks thin and translucent in spots and the surrounding potting mix appears uniformly dark and glossy, suggesting saturation. These clues indicate excess soil moisture has deprived roots of oxygen, causing cellular collapse and initiating rot that manifests as the soft, dark lesions seen. Allow the top 2.5 cm (≈1 in) of soil to dry before the next irrigation and then limit each watering to about 250–300 ml, delivered slowly so it penetrates no deeper than 10 cm (≈4 in). Improve drainage by mixing an extra 20 % coarse perlite or fine bark into the top 5 cm of the medium and slightly raising the container on blocks to let excess water escape. Increase airflow by spacing plants at least 15 cm (6 in) apart and removing any dead foliage that touches the soil to speed surface drying. For the next seven days, feel the soil at 2 cm depth each morning and water only when it is dry and crumbly, observe whether the petiole stiffens and the leaf turgor returns by midday, and inspect the midrib daily for any spread of the dark streak or emergence of white fungal growth as early warning signs.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The lowest trifoliate shows diffuse yellowing with some green veins while newer leaves remain green, indicating nutrient washout typical of excess moisture; the leaf surface is limp rather than crisp; the soil surface is dark-grey, compacted and slightly glossy as if it has stayed wet for long periods; the crown appears pale and elongated, suggesting roots are stretching for oxygen; and the potting mix lacks visible aerating particles, hinting at poor drainage. Taken together, these clues point to water-logging that has reduced oxygen around the fine feeder roots. Immediately allow the top 2 cm (≈1 in) of soil to dry before the next irrigation, then switch to watering no more than 250 ml (≈1 cup) only when that top layer feels dry, and repot within 48 h into a 12 cm-deep container with at least five 0.5 cm drainage holes and a mix of 40 % coarse sand, 40 % coconut coir, 20 % compost. Elevate the pot on a slatted rack to boost underside airflow and avoid saucers that trap runoff. Over the next week, (1) press a fingertip 2 cm deep each morning to confirm the soil is merely moist, not wet; (2) inspect the crown daily for any dark softening that would signal lingering rot; and (3) look for emergence of firm, light-green leaves and cessation of yellow spread on existing foliage as evidence that oxygen and water balance are restored.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The lowest trifoliate shows widespread chlorosis turning to tan necrosis, upper leaves have a limp, slightly dull surface, several petioles have collapsed sideways instead of standing upright, and the soil surface is dark-coloured, clumpy and compacted rather than friable, all indicating excess moisture suffocating roots. Prolonged saturation likely caused root hypoxia, reducing iron and nitrogen uptake and producing the yellow‐brown mottle now visible. Allow the mix to dry until the top 2 cm (≈¾ in) feels dry before the next irrigation, then give only 180–200 ml (≈¾ cup) of water, applied slowly, until you see the first drops exit the drainage holes; thereafter water no more than every 4–5 days. Elevate the pot on small spacers to improve airflow beneath, and gently rake the top 1 cm (⅜ in) of medium to break the crust and speed drying; if possible, blend in 20 % coarse perlite when the plant is repotted to boost drainage. Over the next week, daily: insert a finger to 4 cm (1½ in) depth to confirm the mix is only slightly moist, inspect new central leaves for a healthy green color and upright stance, and sniff the soil for any sour or anaerobic odour; halt watering if any of these checks suggest lingering saturation.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The plant shows several visual indicators: stems are limp and collapse over the pot rim instead of standing upright, the leaflets are pale and flaccid with a slightly translucent sheen, the crown tissue looks darkened and sunken, the bark-chip surface appears consistently wet and glossy, and damp stains are visible on the lower outside of the clay pot. These clues point to prolonged soil saturation that has deprived roots of oxygen, triggering crown/root rot and loss of turgor. Immediately halt watering until the top 3 cm (≈1¼ in) of medium feels dry, then resume at only 150 ml per application every 3–4 days, ensuring water drains fully; raise the pot 1 cm on spacers and lightly loosen the top 2 cm of mix to improve airflow. If the medium stays heavy, repot into a well-draining blend of 50 % pine bark, 30 % coco coir, and 20 % perlite, trimming away any black, mushy roots. Over the next 7 days, each morning insert a finger 5 cm (2 in) deep to confirm the soil is merely moist, not wet; inspect the crown daily for firm, light-brown tissue without spreading dark mush; and watch for new leaves standing more upright with improved color as signs of recovery.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The entire crown is collapsed and lying flat against the potting mix, stems appear water-logged and translucent rather than turgid, the leaves are limp with dull green fading to tan at the margins, the surrounding substrate is uniformly dark and glossy indicating constant saturation, and the barky particles are matted together with no visible airy gaps. These clues point to oxygen starvation and early crown rot from excessive moisture retention. Allow the top 2 cm (¾ in) of soil to dry completely before the next irrigation, then water slowly until only 1 cm (½ in) of runoff emerges from the drainage hole; elevate the pot on spacers to improve airflow underneath and mix 20 % coarse perlite into the top 4 cm (1½ in) to boost drainage. Position the plant where it receives gentle morning sun and good cross-ventilation while avoiding midday heat, and remove any dead foliage to reduce fungal risk. Over the next seven days, press a finger 2 cm into the media each morning and water only if it feels dry, observe whether the crown begins to stand up by at least 1 cm, and check that no new leaf bases show brown mushy tissue or odor—signs that drainage adjustments are working.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The berry surface displays an unusually glossy, water-soaked sheen, and the seeds (achenes) sit noticeably sunken below the swollen flesh. Several translucent patches suggest excess internal moisture, while the fruit droops slightly, indicating loss of firmness. These clues point to the roots remaining in saturated soil, causing cells to overfill with water and weakening skin structure. Cut irrigation back to 1.5 cm (about 0.6 in) of water applied only twice a week in the early morning, and allow the upper 3 cm (1 in) of soil to dry between waterings; lift the plastic mulch edges or pierce small holes every 30 cm (12 in) to improve drainage and airflow. Add a 3 cm (1¼ in) layer of clean straw mulch around crowns to buffer swings in surface moisture and prevent water splash on fruit. Over the next seven days, gently squeeze two random berries each dawn to check for increasing firmness, verify that the soil surface is dry to fingertip depth before the next irrigation, and inspect leaf undersides for pooled condensation that would signal lingering excess humidity.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The stems are limp and collapsed against the soil, the remaining leaf tissue is pale and shriveled, the soil surface looks saturated and glossy black, patches of white fuzzy growth are visible along the crown and soil interface, and darkened stem sections hint at rot. These combined clues indicate prolonged saturation and poor aeration that have stressed the plants and fostered fungi. Allow the top 3 cm (1 in) of soil to dry before each irrigation, then water early morning with no more than 250 ml (≈1 cup) per plant so the upper 5–7 cm is moistened and free drainage is observed. Elevate the container on spacers for better bottom airflow, gently fork the top 2 cm of mix to break any crust, and add a 2 cm (¾ in) layer of coarse bark mulch to moderate moisture swings. Over the next 7 days, daily insert a finger to 3 cm depth and water only if it feels dry, scan for any fresh white mold patches or a sour odor on the surface, and watch for firmer, green new leaves as confirmation of recovery.

Diagnosis: overwatered. Dark, slick soil with no crumbly texture, a glazed almost muddy sheen, and scattered grey-white fuzzy patches on the surface reveal persistent moisture and fungal colonisation. The single runner and stem lie flaccid and pale, while residual leaves are shrivelled and browned at the margins, all consistent with oxygen-starved roots. These combined visual cues indicate that water is being supplied faster than the mix can drain, encouraging saprophytic fungi and root suffocation. Immediately cease watering until the top 3 cm (≈1¼ in) is dry to the touch, then limit irrigation to 200–250 ml only when that layer again dries, ensuring free flow from the pot within 30 s. Lightly fork the upper 2 cm of medium to restore porosity and overlay with 1 cm of coarse perlite or husk chips to improve surface aeration and evaporation; place the pot on 2 cm spacers to keep the base clear and remove all dead foliage to reduce inoculum. Over the next 7 days, feel the top 3 cm of soil each morning for dampness, look for emergence of new firm green leaflets instead of limp tissue, and inspect the surface daily for reappearance of fuzzy mould or a sour smell, adjusting watering and airflow immediately if any of these signs recur.

Diagnosis: overwatered. Dark, glossy soil appears saturated and compacted, suggesting prolonged moisture retention. White, cotton-like fungal mats weave across the soil and dead petioles, a classic sign of excess water encouraging saprophytic growth. Wilted, brown leaf remnants lie flat rather than upright, indicating roots are oxygen-starved in anaerobic conditions. The combination of standing moisture, fungal bloom and decaying tissue points to watering that exceeds the fabric pot’s drainage capacity. Remove all moldy debris and gently rake the top 1 cm of soil to aerate it, then water only when the upper 4 cm (1.5 in) feels dry, applying no more than 200 ml each time. Place the pot on 2 cm (¾ in) spacers to improve airflow underneath and allow free drainage. For the next 7 days, check daily for re-emerging white fuzz, probe soil at 4 cm depth before any watering to confirm dryness, and observe any remaining foliage for a return of turgor rather than continued wilting.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The soil surface is uniformly dark and glossy with a sticky, mud-like texture, fine cracks show it has slumped under excess moisture, and no dry crust is present anywhere; the pot interior is stained, indicating water has stood against the fabric; stems at the crown are black-brown and collapsing, and the remaining leaves are shriveled, grey-green and papery. These visual signs point to chronic saturation that has driven out oxygen, leading to root and crown suffocation. Immediately let the top 5 cm (2 in) of the mix air-dry before any irrigation, then resume watering only when that layer is dry to the touch, giving about 300 ml (10 fl oz) evenly over the surface so that moisture penetrates 10 cm (4 in) deep without pooling; lift the fabric pot onto 2 cm (¾ in) spacers for under-pot airflow and mix 1 cm (½ in) of coarse perlite or pine bark into the upper 2 cm (¾ in) to improve drainage. Over the next week, check daily that your finger inserted 5 cm deep feels cool but not wet, confirm that new crown tissue stays firm and pale rather than darkening, and watch that the soil lightens from black to medium brown with no surface sheen or standing water pockets.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The soil surface is uniformly dark and glossy with no dry crust, indicating persistent saturation; fine white-gray fungal fuzz coats the shriveled petiole stubs; the crown tissue is brown-black and collapsed; remaining leaf blades are pale, curled and papery; and several roots lie exposed, limp and discolored rather than firm and white. These visual cues point to chronic excess moisture that has reduced oxygen around roots, fostered fungal growth, and led to root and crown rot. Immediately cease watering until the top 3 cm (1¼ in) of mix feels dry, then resume with only 150 ml (5 oz) of water every 3–4 days, applied 2 cm (¾ in) away from the crown; raise the fabric pot on a 2 cm (¾ in) slatted rack to speed drainage and airflow; and gently mix 30 % coarse perlite into the upper 5 cm (2 in) of soil while removing all dead stems and leaves with alcohol-wiped scissors, then top with a 1 cm (⅜ in) layer of dry straw mulch. Over the next week, check daily by inserting a finger 3 cm deep to confirm the soil feels cool but not wet before any irrigation; inspect the crown each morning for firm, light-colored tissue instead of dark mush; and look for the surface mold to recede and fine cracks forming on the soil, signaling improved aeration.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The potting mix around the crown is glossy-wet and compacted, several leaflets are limp with darkened, almost black margins, the lower leaves are shriveled and brown, and there is no visible white root growth at the soil surface, all indicating prolonged saturation. Excess moisture likely deprived the roots of oxygen, predisposing them to rot and causing systemic wilting despite abundant water. Immediately drain any standing water, then allow the upper 3 cm (1¼ in) of soil to dry before the next irrigation; thereafter water only until moisture reaches 8 cm (3 in) depth, roughly 250 mL per 15 cm (6 in) pot, every 4–5 days rather than daily. Gently aerate the top layer with a fork to a depth of 2 cm (¾ in) and consider mixing in 20 % coarse perlite or bark at the next transplant to improve drainage. Over the next week, monitor: 1) topsoil dryness by touch each morning, 2) stem base for any soft, dark tissue, and 3) emergence of firm, light-green new leaves which signal recovery; delay watering if the pot still feels heavy or the surface remains cool and moist.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The berries show large, glassy, water-soaked patches that appear translucent compared with the surrounding flesh, several achenes are sunken or surrounded by pale halos, and the skin is splitting in multiple areas while one specimen exhibits early black rot where moisture has pooled. These clues point to excess internal water pressure and tissue breakdown consistent with prolonged saturation rather than insect damage or nutrient burn. Reduce irrigation to a single deep dose of 2 cm (about 0.8 in) once every 4–5 days, allowing the top 5 cm of soil to dry lightly between waterings, and redirect drainage away from the crown with a 3 cm (1.2 in) raised ridge. Improve airflow by thinning nearby foliage to create at least 10 cm (4 in) space between plants and lay 2 cm (0.8 in) of clean straw mulch beneath fruit clusters to keep them off wet soil. Over the next week, gently squeeze five tagged berries each morning to confirm they regain firmness, inspect daily for any new translucent patches or expanding dark lesions, and probe soil at 5 cm depth; if it feels wetter than a wrung-out sponge, postpone the next watering by 24 hours.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The fruit displays broad, pale-pink, water-soaked patches outlined in white (panel A) that contrast sharply with the surrounding firm red tissue, multiple sunken circular lesions where achenes have receded (panel B), and a glassy, translucent appearance to epidermal cells compared with normal turgid cells (panels D vs. E). Surface tissue looks swollen and split at the lesion margins (panel C), and fluorescence imagery (panel G) shows dark, saturated areas consistent with excess internal moisture. These clues together point to prolonged saturation of the root zone, reducing oxygen and driving water up into the developing berries. Immediately cut irrigation back to one deep soak of 2.5 cm (1 in) every 4–5 days instead of daily misting, and ensure water penetrates to 15 cm (6 in) then drains within 30 minutes; if pots, empty saucers after 15 minutes. Improve aeration by gently cultivating the top 2 cm (¾ in) of soil and add a 3 cm (1¼ in) layer of loose straw mulch to regulate surface moisture. Over the next week, daily: 1) push a finger or moisture probe 5 cm (2 in) deep to confirm the top layer dries to just moist before the next watering, 2) squeeze two berries to verify firmness is returning rather than remaining mushy, and 3) inspect new fruit for any fresh translucent or sunken spots, noting percentage of affected fruit each day.

Diagnosis: overwatered. Several leaves are limp with grey-brown blotches and dark, water-stained margins, the petiole bases appear mushy and pale, and the soil surface is shiny, compacted and saturated right up to the rim of the plastic tray, all indicating prolonged excess moisture. Newer foliage is scant and lighter green than the older leaves, and a white, fuzzy sheen is forming on some dying leaf tissue—both signs of root stress and poor airflow brought on by standing water. The likely cause is insufficient drainage in the container, leading to oxygen-starved roots and opportunistic decay organisms that thrive in constantly wet media. Immediately let the top 2 cm (¾ in) of soil dry before the next irrigation, then water only until moisture reaches a depth of 5 cm (2 in) every 4–5 days; tilt or drill three 6 mm (¼ in) holes in the base to improve outflow, and gently fork in 20 % coarse perlite to keep the mix airy. Elevate the pot on spacers to create 1 cm (⅜ in) of clearance for underside airflow, and remove the brownest leaves with clean scissors to reduce rot inoculum. Over the next week, check daily that the soil surface lightens in colour and feels crumbly, look for firmer, upright new leaflets emerging from the crown, and inspect the removed drainage water tray (if any) for standing water—discard it promptly if more than 0.5 cm (¼ in) accumulates.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The potting mix is uniformly dark, glossy and compacted with no lighter dry spots, signalling persistent saturation. Lower and mid-canopy leaves are limp and curling with broad brown-black necrotic patches and a slightly papery surface. Several petioles sprawl flat and pale instead of standing upright, and a faint grey fuzz is visible on some decaying leaf bases. A few newer leaflets are still bright green but smaller, showing the crown is stressed rather than nutrient-deficient. These visual cues together indicate oxygen-starved roots from chronic over-irrigation. Immediately drill or punch 6–8 drainage holes (≈6 mm diameter) in the container base, raise it on 2 cm spacers, and allow the soil to dry until the upper 3 cm feels dry before any watering. After that, provide just 200–250 ml of water per plant every 4–5 days, ensuring moisture reaches about 10 cm deep without leaving standing water, and lightly rake the top 1 cm of soil and add a 1 cm layer of coarse mulch to improve aeration. Over the next 7 days, check daily with a finger that the top 3 cm is only slightly damp, watch for firm upright new leaves emerging from the crown, and inspect older foliage and stems for any fresh grey mold or spreading blackening, removing damaged tissue promptly.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The potting mix is uniformly dark and glossy, several bark chips are water-stained, and no pale, crusty areas are visible, indicating constant saturation. All mature petioles are limp and draped over the rim, the leaf blades are dull silver-green and flaccid, and the crown base shows slight darkening, classic signs of waterlogged, oxygen-deprived roots. Only a small central tuft of new foliage remains upright, demonstrating the plant’s roots are still partly functional but stressed. Excess moisture has likely suffocated fine roots and started crown softening, preventing normal water regulation and causing systemic wilt. Withhold irrigation until the top 3 cm (≈1¼ in) of mix dries, then resume with no more than 150 ml (½ cup) every 3–4 days, applied around the pot edge rather than directly on the crown. Raise the pot 2 cm on feet for improved drainage, pull mulch 2 cm back from the crown, and remove any mushy leaves to enhance airflow and reduce pathogen risk. Over the next 7 days, insert a wooden skewer 4 cm deep each morning to verify it emerges only slightly damp before watering, watch for petioles standing more upright and new leaves unfurling green and firm, and inspect the crown daily for absence of fresh brown or slimy tissue or algae buildup.

Diagnosis: overwatered. I see standing puddles between rows, soil that is glossy and sludge-like in texture, fruit partially submerged and coated with wet silt, dark soft spots beginning on several berries, and stems lying flat rather than upright—each sign typical of water saturation and oxygen-starved roots. These clues indicate that irrigation or rainfall has exceeded the soil’s drainage capacity, keeping the root zone continuously wet. Immediately stop watering for 3–4 days and thereafter irrigate only when the top 2.5 cm (1 in) of soil is dry, delivering no more than 2 cm (0.8 in) of water per session with a drip line rather than flood flow. Fork in 3–4 cm (1.5 in) of coarse compost and raise the bed height by at least 8 cm (3 in) to enhance percolation, then lay a 5 cm (2 in) layer of straw mulch to reduce surface compaction. Over the next week, visually confirm that no water remains on the surface one hour after irrigation, probe soil daily to 5 cm depth to feel for slight moisture rather than saturation, and inspect berries each morning for new mushy or grey patches so corrective drainage measures can be escalated quickly.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The central strawberry displays limp, downward-curving petioles, dull soft leaves that are curling inward, several blotchy yellow-brown leaf tips, and a dark, glossy soil surface that appears consistently moist even in full sun, all suggesting excess moisture around the roots. Such persistent wetness can deprive roots of oxygen, leading to root rot and the generalized wilting seen despite apparently ample water. Immediately cut back irrigation to one deep soaking of about 1.5 L (roughly 0.4 gal) every 4–5 days, aiming for moisture only to 5 cm/2 in depth; let the top 2 cm/¾ in of soil dry before the next watering. Gently cultivate a 20 cm/8 in wide ring around the crown and mix in 2 cm/¾ in of coarse compost or perlite to improve drainage, and keep foliage off the soil by laying a 3 cm/1 in layer of clean straw mulch. Over the next week, check each morning for (1) soil that lightens in color and feels barely damp at 2 cm depth, (2) newly emerging leaves that stand upright and feel firm, and (3) absence of any sour smell or dark mushy tissue at the crown; adjust watering only if two of these three indicators trend negative.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The potting mix is uniformly dark and glossy, indicating constant saturation; the crown tissue shows orange-brown translucence suggestive of rot; wilted leaf petioles lie flat against the soil instead of standing upright; older leaflets are crisp and greyish while the youngest tip is pale yellow, pointing to root suffocation; no new white feeder roots are visible at the surface. Together these clues align with chronic excess moisture that has deprived roots of oxygen and initiated crown decay. Immediately let the pot drain fully, then irrigate only when the top 1–1.5 cm (½ inch) of soil feels dry, supplying roughly 40–50 ml of water slowly so it wets to a 5 cm (2 inch) depth; elevate the peat pot on a slatted rack to keep its base from standing in runoff and improve airflow; gently remove the top 0.5 cm of soggy mix and replace with dry, coarse compost to wick moisture away from the crown. Over the next week, check daily for: (1) soil surface lightening in colour before each watering, (2) any firm, white new growth emerging at the crown rather than soft brown tissue, and (3) leaves regaining turgor within 12 hours of each controlled watering session. If soil remains shiny for more than 24 hours or crown tissue turns darker brown, withhold water and increase ventilation until conditions improve.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The potting mix is glossy-black, clumped and shiny, older trifoliate leaves are dark brown-black and papery, the green leaf in the foreground appears slightly limp with dulled edges, and the crown sits level with persistently wet soil lacking any dry crust. These visual clues together point to chronic waterlogging that is starving roots of oxygen and fostering rot. Allow the top 3 cm (≈1¼ in) of soil to dry completely before each irrigation, then water only 200 ml every 4 days, making sure excess drains through three 6 mm holes and elevating the tray 1 cm on spacers to boost airflow beneath. Incorporate a 1 cm (⅜ in) surface layer of coarse perlite or bark to keep pores open, and prune away the blackened leaves with sterilised scissors to improve sanitation and reduce moisture retention around the crown. Over the next week, insert a finger to 3 cm depth each morning to confirm dryness before watering, watch for new leaves emerging upright and bright green, and ensure no additional foliage develops brown or mushy patches near the base. Each evening inspect the drainage holes for blockages and verify that no standing water remains in the tray.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The strawberry shows water-soaked, translucent patches, a generally swollen and misshapen surface, sunken seed pockets, and slight dullness rather than the bright sheen typical of a well-ripened fruit, while surrounding foliage appears lush and uniformly dark—signs that roots have remained in saturated soil. These visual cues point to excess moisture limiting oxygen around the crown and fruit, leading to cell rupture and softness. Reduce irrigation to no more than 2 cm (¾ in) of water total per week, delivered in one deep morning soak; allow the upper 2.5 cm (1 in) of soil to dry before the next watering. Lift plants slightly by adding a 3 cm (1¼ in) layer of coarse straw mulch to improve evaporation and keep fruit off wet ground, and if beds are flat, create shallow channels 8 cm (3 in) wide between rows to drain standing water. Over the next seven days, feel soil at 5 cm (2 in) depth each morning—if it sticks heavily to fingers, skip watering; gently squeeze two ripening berries daily to confirm they regain firmness; and inspect lower leaves for any gray or white fungal fuzz that could exploit lingering moisture, removing affected tissue immediately with sanitized scissors.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The central petiole is limp and arched to the soil surface, the two visible leaves droop instead of standing upright, and the soil directly around the crown looks uniformly dark and glossy, suggesting persistent moisture. No scorch or yellowing is present, implying roots are oxygen-starved rather than nutrient-deficient, and the surrounding medium appears compacted, further limiting air exchange. Excess water is therefore the most plausible stressor causing loss of turgor. Allow the top 3 cm (about 1¼ in) of soil to dry before the next irrigation, then apply only 1 cm (⅜ in) of water—roughly 500 ml per plant—every 4–5 days, delivered early morning so foliage dries quickly. Loosen the surface with a hand fork to 2 cm depth to improve aeration, and if possible raise the bed edge or add 1 cm of coarse compost to enhance drainage. Over the next week, check daily that the crown sits slightly above the surrounding mix and that no standing water forms after watering; press a finger 3 cm down to confirm the soil is just moist, not wet; and observe whether new central leaves emerge firm and upright without dark lesions, indicating recovery.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The leaves are limp and laying flat against the soil, stems lack rigidity, and several leaflets show a pale, washed-out green tint rather than a firm glossy sheen. The soil immediately around each crown appears darker and slightly sunken, suggesting recent saturation while surrounding areas are drier and crumbly. Fine silt has crusted on the surface, another sign of repeated wetting and drying cycles. These clues point to excess irrigation that has reduced root oxygen, leading to the visible wilting despite otherwise intact foliage. Allow the top 3 cm (1¼ in) of soil to dry fully before the next watering, then irrigate no more than 1–1.5 cm (⅜–⅝ in) of water every 4–5 days, delivered early morning. Lightly fork in 2–3 cm (¾–1 in) of coarse compost around each plant to improve drainage and create a slight mound so crowns sit 2 cm (¾ in) above the surrounding grade. Add a 2 cm (¾ in) layer of straw mulch after the soil has dried to moderate future moisture swings. Over the next seven days, check soil moisture at 5 cm (2 in) depth with your finger each morning, note whether leaves regain upright posture at sunrise, and inspect crowns for any new softness or gray fungal fuzz, adjusting water only if two of these indicators still signal excess moisture.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The substrate appears consistently dark and glossy between the perlite particles, several leaves are wilted and lying flat rather than held upright, margins and tips of two leaves are turning tan-brown and papery, and the petioles look soft and slightly translucent near the crown—all classic signs of water-saturated roots unable to supply oxygen. Excess moisture likely caused root hypoxia and the early onset of crown rot, leading to the observed collapse and browning. Allow the pot to drain fully, then withhold irrigation until the top 2.5 cm (about 1 in) of mix is completely dry; thereafter water only enough to moisten to a depth of 5 cm (2 in) every 4–5 days, ensuring free flow from the bottom holes. Elevate the container on a 1 cm (½ in) mesh or spacers to improve drainage, and run a small fan to keep gentle airflow around foliage at least 15 cm (6 in) away from leaves. Over the next week, visually confirm that the soil surface lightens in color within 24 h of watering, check daily that new central leaves stand firm and glossy rather than limp, and inspect the crown base for any dark or mushy tissue—halt watering immediately if these symptoms reappear.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The soil surface appears uniformly dark and glossy, indicating constant saturation, and several lower leaves are wilted, dull grey-green, and edged with bronze-brown desiccation. Petioles lie flat and look soft rather than upright and firm, and some crowns show dark, mushy tissue where they meet the soil. A few older leaves are fully collapsed and blackened, suggesting early root or crown rot consistent with prolonged excess moisture. These visual cues point to oxygen starvation in the root zone from too-frequent watering. Allow the top 2–3 cm (≈1 in) of mix to dry before the next irrigation, then give only about 200 ml (≈¾ cup) of water, applied slowly and evenly, so it penetrates 10 cm (4 in) without pooling. Drill or confirm four 6 mm (¼ in) drainage holes in the base and raise the container on small spacers to improve airflow; optionally incorporate a 1 cm layer of coarse mulch on top to moderate evaporation. Remove the mushy, blackened leaves with clean scissors and discard them to reduce pathogen pressure. For the next 7 days, visually check each morning that the soil surface has lightened in color, that petioles are regaining firmness and standing at a 30–45° angle, and that no new brown or black lesions appear at the crown; postpone watering until at least two of these signs are positive.

Diagnosis: overwatered. The foliage is uniformly limp and laying flat against the lid, the petioles are elongated and pale green rather than upright and firm, several leaflets show a dull, dark-green sheen instead of a lively matte finish, and the clay pebbles at the crown appear constantly glossy with moisture, indicating saturation. These visual cues point to excess solution level that has kept the roots submerged, reducing oxygen and collapsing turgor. Immediately drop the nutrient-water line so it sits 2.5 cm (≈1 in) below the bottom of the net cup, install or increase an airstone bubbling at least 1 L min⁻¹, and let only the bottom 1–1.5 cm (≈½ in) of the pebbles stay damp while the upper layer dries between top-ups. Re-check solution depth every 48 h and add water only when it has fallen 4 cm (≈1½ in) below the new mark; at that point refill just to the 2.5 cm line to maintain a moist-but-aerated zone. Over the next 7 days look for petioles regaining partial uprightness within 48 h, emergence of firm white root tips through the net cup by day 5, and drying of the upper pebble layer to a light tan color rather than the current wet gloss—any failure in these three checks signals persistent over-saturation and the need for further lowering of the water level or increased aeration.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Several outer leaves are shriveled, papery-brown and lying flat on the straw, while only a small inner tuft remains green, indicating die-back that starts at the base; many petioles are yellowed at mid-section, and a few fruits are collapsed and dark, pointing to disrupted water uptake; the discoloration is patchy but radiates evenly from the crown, suggesting a root or crown-level issue rather than leaf-surface infection; surrounding straw looks matted and possibly water-logged, hinting at prolonged moisture around the root zone. These clues collectively align with a water-saturated medium fostering Phytophthora/Pythium root rot. Action: pull straw 4–5 cm (≈2 in) back from the crown to let the upper root zone dry and improve airflow; irrigate only when the top 5 cm (≈2 in) of soil is dry, then apply 2 cm (≈¾ in) of water early morning so roots are moist but not flooded; fork in 2 cm of coarse compost around, not over, the crown to raise the planting height slightly and enhance drainage. Sanitation: clip and discard all brown leaves and sunken fruits, wiping pruners with 70 % alcohol between cuts to limit pathogen spread. For the next 7 days, check each morning that the soil at 5 cm depth is moist but not sticking to your finger, inspect the crown for firmness rather than mushiness, and look for any newly wilted leaves despite adequate soil moisture; absence of further wilt and a firm, pale crown will signal recovery.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Dark, water-soaked roots with few white feeder tips, a sunken reddish-brown crown, and several outer leaves turned papery brown while inner foliage remains pale green all point to a systemic root decline concentrated at the crown and root zone. These clues align with excess moisture and poor drainage that favor soilborne fungi attacking the root cortex. Immediately improve drainage by replanting into a 15–20 cm-high raised row amended with 5 cm of coarse compost and sand, and switch to drip irrigation delivering no more than 1.5 cm of water every three days in the early morning so the upper 5 cm of soil dries by nightfall. Remove and discard all visibly affected plants plus the surrounding 10 cm of soil debris, and mulch the bed with a 2 cm layer of clean straw to reduce splash and keep crowns dry. Over the next seven days, inspect plants every other day for new leaf wilt or darkening at the crown, gently tug crowns to confirm they stay firmly anchored (a loose crown signals ongoing rot), and look for the return of bright white root tips as a sign of recovery.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The root system shows extensive dark brown to black tissue with very few healthy white strands, several lower leaves display a reddish-brown burn starting at the margins and moving inward, and many petioles are limp or shriveled, indicating systemic water stress. The crown area is discolored and partially collapsed, and overall foliage has an uneven mix of faded green and dry, papery sections. These patterns together point to roots suffocated and invaded by moisture-loving fungi after prolonged saturation or poor drainage. Immediately lift and replant survivors into a raised bed or mound at least 15 cm high using a mix amended with 30 % coarse compost and sand, and remove all dark, mushy roots with sterile shears. Irrigate only when the top 3 cm of soil feels dry, delivering about 2 cm of water evenly around the drip line in the early morning, and spread a 3 cm coarse straw mulch to keep crowns dry while improving airflow. Over the next 7 days, check soil moisture daily by inserting a finger 5 cm deep, gently tug crowns every other day to confirm they remain firm rather than soft, and inspect new leaf bases for any fresh reddish lesions or slimy tissue to ensure the rot is no longer advancing.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The lower 3–5 cm of the crowns are dark brown-black and water-soaked, many fine feeder roots are missing or appear slimy, and surviving roots are tan rather than white. Several mid-canopy leaves are wilted and have irregular brown necrotic patches, while older leaflets curl and crisp along the margins, indicating impaired water uptake. Root mass is noticeably reduced and clings together in a decomposing mat, with a damp earthy odor visible through clumped media. These combined symptoms point to rot initiated by prolonged saturation and poor aeration that favors soil-borne pathogens such as Phytophthora or Pythium attacking the root cortex. Immediately improve drainage by planting in a 20 cm (8 in) high raised bed or ridged row and water only when the top 3 cm (1¼ in) of soil is dry, applying 1.5 cm (½ in) of water via drip over 15 minutes in early morning. Remove and discard any plants whose crowns are more than 50 % blackened, and mulch with a 2 cm (¾ in) layer of coarse composted bark to keep soil surface aerated while suppressing splashing. Increase airflow by spacing plants 30 cm (12 in) apart and trimming runners weekly. Over the next 7 days, inspect daily for emergence of white new feeder roots at the crown junction, check afternoon leaf turgor to confirm recovery, and gently tug plants every two days to note whether anchoring strength improves; lack of these positive signs signals continued rot that will require further sanitation measures.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Dark brown to almost black discoloration extends from the crown down the upper roots, the root system is sparse with many feeder roots missing, the remaining roots look stringy and water-soaked, several lower leaves are entirely necrotic and curled brown, and the crown zone is visibly dark and constricted compared with healthy tan tissue. These collected clues indicate active root rot triggered by prolonged saturation and poor drainage that encourage soil-borne fungi such as Phytophthora or Pythium. Immediately transplant or mound the plant onto a raised bed at least 15 cm high and incorporate 30 % coarse compost or perlite into the top 20 cm of soil; thereafter irrigate in the early morning every 3–4 days, delivering about 2.5 cm (1 in) of water and allowing the upper 2 cm to dry before the next cycle. Prune away all blackened roots to firm white tissue and remove the brown leaves, disinfecting tools for 1 min in 10 % bleach between cuts and discarding debris off-site. Lay a 3 cm straw mulch layer but keep a 2 cm gap around the crown to boost airflow and reduce splash-back. During the next 7 days, check soil moisture daily by inserting a finger 5 cm deep to verify it is only slightly damp, inspect the crown every second day for spreading black lesions or softness, and look for the appearance of new white feeder roots and perked-up green leaves as early recovery signs.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The primary root mass is predominantly dark brown to black rather than creamy white, fine feeder roots are sparse or missing, and several roots appear stringy and water-soaked; additionally, the crown tissue shows a reddish-brown band extending about 2–3 cm upward, and multiple lower leaves exhibit yellowing with dry brown necrotic patches. Such discoloration, tissue collapse, and leaf decline point to oxygen starvation and secondary infection by water-borne pathogens consistent with root rot. Correct conditions by replanting in a raised bed or mound at least 20 cm high with well-drained mix, irrigating only when the top 4 cm of soil is dry and then applying no more than 2 cm of water evenly, and adding a 3 cm layer of coarse mulch around (but 2 cm clear of) the crown to moderate moisture. Improve airflow by trimming dead leaves and maintaining 30 cm plant spacing to hasten soil surface drying. Over the next 7 days, visually check daily for standing water or sour odor around the base, note whether new white feeder roots appear at the crown when gently exposed, and confirm that emerging leaves stay turgid and uniformly green without further wilt or spotting.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The root mass shows extensive dark brown to nearly black discoloration with very few fine white feeder roots, indicating tissue decay; several roots appear water-soaked and stringy, and some have collapsed tips. Above-ground, lower leaves are wilted with a papery brown necrotic patch, and runners are thin and pale, all pointing to impaired water uptake originating in the root zone. These visual cues collectively suggest water-logged conditions that have favored soil-borne pathogens such as Phytophthora or Pythium. Immediately improve drainage by raising the bed 15–20 cm and irrigating only when the top 3 cm of soil is dry, delivering no more than 2.5 cm of water in one early-morning session every 4–5 days; ensure water reaches 10 cm depth but drains within 2 hours. Gently remove any obviously rotted roots, then mulch with a 2 cm coarse straw layer to moderate surface moisture and temperature, and space plants 25 cm apart to enhance airflow around crowns. Over the next 7 days, daily probe the root zone to 5 cm depth for excess moisture, inspect the crown base for any spreading dark lesions, and watch new leaves for restored turgor and healthy green color; halt all watering if soil remains wet or if additional roots turn black.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The exposed root system is mostly dark brown-to-black, water-soaked and matted, with few healthy cream-colored feeder roots visible, and several strands look collapsed rather than firm. Attached leaves show patchy yellowing and necrotic margins, especially on runners closest to the damaged crown, indicating impaired water uptake from diseased roots. These visual signs point to roots suffocating in overly wet, poorly drained soil that has favored pathogenic fungi responsible for root rot. Lift the plant and re-establish it on a 15 cm (6 in) high, well-drained mound amended with 30 % coarse sand or perlite, then irrigate only when the top 2 cm (¾ in) of soil is dry, applying no more than 2 cm (¾ in) of water in the early morning. Trim away all blackened roots with sterilized scissors and discard them; afterward spread a 3 cm (1¼ in) layer of clean straw mulch to regulate surface moisture without sealing in excess humidity. Over the next 7 days, visually confirm that new root tips emerging at the crown are white and firm, check each evening that the mulch surface feels dry rather than wet, and watch daily for fresh green leaves free of yellowing or midday wilting as indicators of recovery.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Dark brown-black fibrous roots encircle a crown whose center is translucent orange-brown and water-soaked, indicating advanced tissue breakdown. The outer crown surface looks shriveled and brittle, and a pale necrotic spot sits in the middle of the moist core, showing progression from the root upward. Such moisture-saturated, discolored crown tissue strongly suggests root rot initiated by excess water that enabled soil-borne fungi to invade. Raise the bed or mound soil 15–20 cm and blend in 5 cm of coarse compost to improve drainage, then irrigate only when the top 3 cm of soil feels dry, applying no more than 2 cm of water in the early morning twice per week. Remove and discard every plant showing similar rot, cutting at least 5 cm above the discolored area, and disinfect tools for 60 s in a 10 % bleach solution before reuse. Lay a 3–4 cm layer of clean straw mulch around remaining crowns to reduce soil splash and keep the crown bases slightly elevated. Over the next seven days, inspect crowns daily for any fresh darkening or softening, probe soil moisture at 5 cm depth to confirm it dries within 24 h after watering, and watch for new wilting or sour odors that would indicate continuing infection.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The exposed root system shows widespread black to dark brown discoloration, a slimy texture, loss of fine feeder roots, and sections where the root cortex has sloughed off, leaving stringy vascular strands, all indicating active decay. The crown base is still pale while the roots are almost entirely necrotic, and there are no healthy white rootlets visible, confirming the problem begins below the soil line. This pattern is consistent with roots kept too wet and oxygen-starved, giving soil-borne fungi such as Phytophthora or Pythium an advantage. Reduce irrigation immediately to no more than 2 cm (¾ in) of water every four days, applied at dawn, and raise the bed or pot by 20 cm (8 in) using a coarse, bark- or perlite-amended mix to improve drainage and airflow. Remove all black or mushy roots with sterile scissors and discard them, then top the soil with a 1 cm (⅜ in) layer of clean straw mulch to reduce future splash and compaction. Over the next seven days, check soil moisture at 5 cm (2 in) depth each morning—soil should feel only slightly damp, inspect newly emerging root tips for a return to creamy-white color, and watch the crown for any renewed darkening or wilt so irrigation or drainage can be adjusted promptly.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The crown tissue appears dark brown to nearly black with a leathery, shriveled texture, several petioles are desiccated and curled, the main root mass is sparse and shows widespread dark discoloration rather than healthy white, and many fine feeder roots are missing or brittle. These combined clues point to prolonged saturation and poor aeration that favored soil-borne pathogens such as Phytophthora or Pythium, leading to systemic decay of crown and roots. Immediately improve drainage by raising the planting bed 20–25 cm and incorporating 30 % coarse compost or sand; thereafter irrigate only when the top 5 cm of soil is dry, delivering about 2 cm of water in the early morning so excess can drain away. Remove and discard visibly rotted plant remnants, then apply a 2 cm layer of clean straw mulch kept at least 3 cm from the crown to reduce splashing and maintain airflow.
