Over the next seven days, probe soil 5 cm deep daily to ensure it is moist but not waterlogged, inspect new root tips for emergence of firm white growth instead of brown strands, and gently squeeze the crown every two days to confirm it remains firm rather than soft or mushy.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The sliced crown shows a broad band of dark brown vascular discoloration encircling the pith, the outer crown tissue has turned water-soaked tan rather than firm white, the fine feeder roots are sparse and mostly blackened, and several root tips appear shriveled, indicating decay progressing upward from the soil line. Such a pattern is typical of root and crown infections by water-borne fungi that thrive in saturated, poorly aerated media. Immediately raise the planting zone by 20–25 cm with well-drained composted mix, then irrigate only when the top 2 cm of soil is dry, applying no more than 3 cm of water in a single session and allowing full drainage within 2 hours; avoid late-day watering. Improve airflow by spacing neighboring plants at least 25 cm apart and removing dead leaf litter, and lay a 3 cm coarse straw mulch to reduce splash dispersal. Over the next 7 days, inspect the crown base daily for any fresh amber exudate or advancing brown streaks, gently tug on plants every two days to confirm roots are firm rather than sliding free, and look for the emergence of new white feeder roots at the soil surface during each inspection.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Several fine feeder roots appear dark brown-to-black rather than tan, many are missing bark and have a brittle texture, and the remaining crown roots show patchy decay concentrated near the soil line; these discolorations are irregular and progress upward, indicating active rot. The surrounding soil looks heavy and compacted with clods adhering to roots, suggesting poor drainage and prolonged moisture that favors rot pathogens. White, C-shaped larvae and gnawed root surfaces are visible, implying secondary root-feeding weevils exploiting already weakened tissue. Excess moisture combined with opportunistic fungi such as Pythium/Phytophthora is therefore the most likely primary cause. Immediately lift the planting bed by 8–10 cm and incorporate 4 cm of coarse compost or sand to improve percolation; thereafter irrigate only when the top 4 cm of soil is dry, applying no more than 2.5 cm of water in a single session. Remove and discard the most severely rotted plants plus 5 cm of adjacent soil, and mulch with a 2 cm layer of clean straw to reduce soil splash. Over the next 7 days, probe soil moisture at 5 cm depth each morning to keep it just moist, inspect exposed crown roots for any new blackening or softening, and look for additional larvae or adult weevils at dusk so they can be hand-picked before they spread.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Multiple leaves display irregular reddish-brown blotches, marginal browning, and scattered wilting, while adjacent foliage remains pale green, suggesting patchy stress originating belowground; several crowns appear slightly sunken within a straw-mulched row, and overall plant vigor is reduced compared with expected dense, upright growth. These visual cues point to roots struggling in pockets of excess moisture that favor rot pathogens, most likely Phytophthora or Rhizoctonia, which block water uptake and cause the observed top-side scorch and collapse. Immediately improve drainage by gently lifting the existing row 5–7 cm with added composted bark and creating shallow side channels so standing water moves away after rain; irrigate only when the top 4 cm of soil feels dry, applying 1.5–2 cm of water in the early morning every 4–5 days rather than daily trickles. Pull straw mulch 3–4 cm back from each crown to expose the crown base and allow quicker surface drying, and thin dense foliage to one healthy runner every 15 cm to boost airflow. Over the next week, inspect soil moisture at 5 cm depth with a finger probe each morning, watch for new firm, light-colored roots at the crown edge, and note whether midday leaf wilting lessens by day 7; also check for any spread of reddish lesions to newly emerged leaves as an early warning of continuing root decay.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The two left root systems exhibit dark brown to nearly black crowns, water-soaked primary roots, and a striking lack of fine feeder hairs, while the right root mass is dense, light golden, and fibrous; the unhealthy samples also look thin, translucent, and sparsely branched. Such discoloration, tissue loss, and sogginess visually indicate fungal root rot promoted by chronically wet, poorly drained soil. Raise the entire strawberry bed 15–20 cm and blend 5 cm of coarse composted bark or perlite into the top 20 cm to improve aeration, then switch to drip irrigation that supplies about 2.5 cm of water once every 5–7 days only after the upper 5 cm of soil feels dry. Remove and discard all plants with blackened roots, trimming tools between cuts in a 10 % bleach solution for 60 seconds, and spread a 3 cm layer of clean straw mulch to moderate moisture and temperature. Over the next week, every other day gently expose a small root section to verify new white feeder roots, press the crown to ensure it stays firm rather than mushy, and note whether the soil odor shifts from sour to earthy; additionally, check midday leaf turgor and record any decline in wilting.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Exposed roots display patchy tan-to-dark-brown discoloration, several segments near the crown are blackened and constricted, fine feeder roots are sparse or missing, and the remaining thicker roots look water-soaked and slightly shriveled. These visual symptoms point to rot developing under chronically saturated, poorly drained conditions that favor soil-borne pathogens which attack and collapse the vascular tissue. Immediately raise the planting area or add a 15–20 cm high, well-drained berm and water only when the top 2 cm of soil feels dry, delivering about 2 cm of water evenly in early morning to avoid standing moisture; incorporate a 3 cm layer of coarse straw or pine-bark mulch to keep surface moisture stable yet airy, and space crowns at least 30 cm apart to improve airflow. Remove and discard visibly blackened root sections with sterilized pruners and rinse remaining roots briefly to clear soggy debris before replanting into fresh, well-drained mix. Over the next 7 days, lift a small edge plug daily to verify that new root tips are white and firm, probe soil at 5 cm depth so it stays damp but never dripping, and check foliage each afternoon for reduced wilting or yellowing as an external confirmation that root function is improving.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The crown center is vividly orange-brown with a wet, gelatinous texture, the surrounding crown tissue has sunken dark margins, and most peripheral roots are black, brittle, and sparsely branched; attached leaf bases are shriveled and tan, and a few fine roots remain pale only at the tips. These clues point to a moisture-favored fungal infection that invaded through saturated soil, leading to crown and root decay and disruption of water flow. Immediately remove and discard the affected plant and any adjacent soil within a 6 cm radius, then irrigate remaining plants only when the top 3 cm of soil is dry, applying no more than 2.5 cm (1 in.) of water every 4 days to keep the root zone moist but aerated. Improve drainage by raising beds 15 cm and incorporating 5 cm of coarse compost, and lay a 2 cm layer of clean straw mulch to reduce splash and keep crowns dry. Sanitize cutting tools with 70 % alcohol between plants and avoid overhead watering, especially in late afternoon. Over the next 7 days, visually check daily that newly exposed crown tissue remains firm and cream-white (not orange-brown), confirm that emerging feeder roots extend at least 1–2 cm and stay white, and watch the youngest leaves for renewed turgor or any fresh wilting that would signal continuing rot spread.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The crowns display patchy dark-brown to nearly black discoloration extending upward 1–2 cm, outer tissues appear water-soaked and mushy, fine feeder roots are sparse and tan instead of white, and several cut crowns show a clear boundary where healthy pale tissue transitions to reddish necrosis. Tiny wilted leaf stubs remain attached, indicating collapse started from the root–crown junction rather than the foliage, and all plants look uniformly affected, suggesting a soil-borne infection rather than isolated mechanical damage. These clues point to a water-favored oomycete or similar pathogen attacking saturated crowns. Immediately improve drainage by raising beds 15 cm and watering only when the top 3 cm of soil is dry, delivering 2 cm of water early morning once every 4–5 days instead of daily sprinkling; incorporate coarse compost or perlite at least 5 cm deep around remaining plants to boost porosity, and remove all visibly rotted crowns, disposing of them off-site. Lay a 2 cm straw mulch to reduce soil splash and maintain even moisture while still allowing airflow around the crown. Over the next 7 days, check that irrigation never leaves standing water for more than 30 minutes, inspect crown bases daily for any new soft brown lesions wider than 2 mm, and gently tug plants every second day—any that loosen easily or smell sour should be culled promptly.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The sample shows sparse, thread-thin roots with missing lateral fibrous roots, tan to dark-brown streaking running vertically up the crown, a water-soaked translucent zone near the crown base, and an overall shrunken, wilted root collar, all consistent with rot initiated in saturated media. These clues point to excess moisture and poor drainage that favor soil-borne pathogens (e.g., Pythium or Phytophthora) attacking fine feeder roots and crown tissues. Immediately pull back irrigation to a single deep watering of 2 cm (≈0.8 in) once soil at 5 cm depth feels dry, raise the planting row or container by at least 20 cm (≈8 in) to improve runoff, and mix in 3 cm (≈1¼ in) of coarse compost or perlite to boost aeration; remove and discard the visibly rotted plant parts and disinfect cutting tools for 1 min in a 10 % bleach solution. Over the next week, daily check soil moisture with a finger or probe at 5 cm depth, gently expose one plant per row to look for the emergence of firm white feeder roots, and inspect crowns for any new browning or softening, intervening by loosening soil or adding dry mulch if saturation reappears.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The extracted crown shows patchy olive-green fungal growth along several root sheaths, dark brown water-soaked lesions at the crown base, shriveled reddish-brown roots, and complete loss of fine white feeder roots, all concentrating near the lowest 1–2 cm, indicating active decay rather than mechanical damage. Such discoloration, tissue collapse, and surface mycelium are consistent with water-logged conditions favoring root-rotting fungi. Immediately improve drainage by raising the bed or container 15 cm and irrigate only when the top 4 cm of soil are dry, applying no more than 2 cm of water in each session early in the morning; maintain a loose, well-aerated mulch layer 5 cm thick of coarse straw to keep surface roots cool while allowing airflow; and discard the affected plant and sanitize tools with 10 % bleach for one minute to avoid spreading spores. Over the next seven days, inspect remaining plants daily for (1) emergence of new white root tips when lightly brushed free of soil, (2) crown firmness when gently squeezed—any softening signals trouble, and (3) absence of new olive or brown streaks on surface roots or mulch; record findings each morning to verify recovery or prompt further action.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The crown base shows a dark reddish-brown band and soft, water-soaked tissue, the fine roots are sparse and blackened, upper leaves are dull olive with necrotic tips, and some petals of dead tissue cling to the crown, all indicating collapse that begins below the soil line. These visual signs align with rot caused by excess moisture and poor drainage that encourage soil-borne fungi attacking the crown and feeder roots. Immediately lift the surrounding soil into a raised bed at least 20 cm (8 in) high and incorporate 5 cm (2 in) of coarse compost to improve drainage; thereafter irrigate only when the top 2 cm (¾ in) of soil is dry, delivering about 2 cm (¾ in) of water early in the morning so foliage dries quickly. Remove and discard (do not compost) the affected plant and sanitize tools with a 10 % bleach solution for 1 minute to limit spread. Over the next 7 days, confirm that newly transplanted or adjacent plants maintain firm, white crowns when gently probed, log soil moisture at 5 cm depth each morning, and inspect lower leaves for any fresh dark streaking or wilt to catch recurring rot early.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Rows of strawberry plants show widespread mid-row bands of straw-colored, wilted foliage, brown desiccated crowns, and near-total collapse of entire plants, while surrounding soil appears compacted and slightly gray, indicating chronic moisture imbalance; surviving edge plants retain some green leaves but are noticeably stunted, and die-back follows the planting line rather than individual spots. These patterns point to root rot developing from prolonged saturation and poor drainage along the beds, causing decay of fine roots and crowns and subsequent top-growth collapse. Immediately deepen surface drainage furrows to at least 15 cm and reshape beds to 20 cm height to keep crowns above water; switch to low-flow drip delivering roughly 1.3 cm (0.5 in) of water every 3 days instead of overhead irrigation; remove and destroy all visibly necrotic plants and incorporate 5 cm (2 in) of coarse composted bark between rows to increase soil porosity. Over the next week, probe soil at 10 cm depth each morning and ensure it crumbles rather than smears; inspect newly exposed crown bases for fresh white roots versus brown mush; and walk the central rows daily, flagging any additional plants whose leaves lose turgor before noon for rapid removal to limit pathogen spread.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The crown tissue appears dark brown and water-soaked, the fine feeder roots are mostly absent or shriveled black, several petiole bases show a yellow-green band fading into brown necrosis, the remaining roots are sparse and brittle, and the emerging leaflets are stunted and slightly wilted. These patterns point to anaerobic, saturated conditions that favor soil-borne rot fungi attacking the crown and roots. Immediately lift remaining plants onto a 15–20 cm high raised ridge, irrigate only at dawn with about 2 cm of water when the top 3 cm of soil feels dry, and mix 3–4 cm of coarse compost or pine bark into the upper 10 cm of soil to speed drainage and aeration; discard visibly rotted plants and rinse tools in hot water for at least 30 sec before re-use. Mulch lightly with 2 cm of clean straw to suppress splashing and keep crowns dry while still allowing airflow, and avoid overhead watering during the next week. Over the next 7 days, check each morning for (1) firm, white interior when a crown is sliced lengthwise (no new browning), (2) appearance of new white root tips at least 0.5 cm long, and (3) soil moisture by inserting a finger 5 cm deep—if it feels cool and wet, delay irrigation until only slightly damp; note any sour smell or further crown collapse and act promptly if observed.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The main feeder root shows a continuous reddish-brown streak running through the stele, the surrounding cortex is pale and water-soaked, small fibrous roots appear missing or shriveled, and adjacent root tissue looks mushy rather than firm. These patterns point to pathogenic decay promoted by prolonged saturation and poor soil aeration. Immediately raise the bed or row by at least 20 cm (8 in) and incorporate 5 cm (2 in) of coarse composted bark to improve drainage, then limit irrigation to 1.3 cm (0.5 in) applied only when the top 4 cm (1.5 in) of soil is dry. Clear any plant debris within a 30 cm (12 in) radius and mulch lightly with 3 cm (1 in) of clean straw to reduce splash and keep crowns dry. Over the next 7 days, inspect roots from one test plant every two days for new brown streaking past the crown, check soil moisture at 5 cm depth with your finger or probe each morning, and observe foliage at midday for sudden wilting that would signal persistent root failure.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The interior crown displays a brown-black discoloration while the outer cortex is sloughing, several primary roots are shriveled and dark rather than creamy white, and fine feeder roots are almost completely absent, leaving a sparse, brittle network. Moist, necrotic tissue is concentrated around the crown center, and the healthy green foliage abruptly transitions to wilted, chlorotic petioles near the base. These patterns point to water-logged, poorly aerated soil encouraging Phytophthora/Pythium fungi that suffocate and decay root tissue. Immediately lift all affected plants, loosen the bed, and incorporate 5 cm (2 in) of coarse compost and sand to improve drainage; replant on raised ridges at least 15 cm (6 in) high. Irrigate only when the top 4 cm (1.5 in) of soil is dry, applying 2.5 cm (1 in) of water early morning so excess drains before evening. Remove and discard any mushy roots and sanitize tools with 70 % alcohol between plants. Over the next 7 days, probe soil daily to confirm it dries to finger-tip depth by sunset, inspect new root tips for white firm growth, and check that no additional crowns show darkening at the soil line.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The finer roots are uniformly dark brown to black instead of creamy white, many are missing or threadlike and brittle, and several thicker roots have a water-soaked, slightly glossy surface, all typical of decay. A softened, black-streaked crown base and the wilted, pale foliage above it further confirm that the infection is progressing upward. Such symptoms strongly suggest prolonged soil saturation that allowed Phytophthora/Pythium fungi to colonize the root zone. Remove and discard the affected plant and any adjacent soil within a 10 cm (4 in) radius, irrigating the remaining bed only when the top 2 cm (¾ in) of soil is dry and then applying no more than 2 cm (¾ in) of water so moisture penetrates to about 10 cm (4 in) depth without puddling. Raise or re-shape rows so crowns sit at least 15 cm (6 in) above the surrounding path and incorporate coarse compost or sand to speed drainage; keep a loose 3 cm (1¼ in) layer of clean straw mulch to moderate moisture while allowing airflow. Disinfect pruning knives and trowels with 70 % alcohol after each plant to prevent spreading spores. Over the next 7 days, press the crown gently each morning to confirm it stays firm, probe the upper 2 cm of soil for dryness before every irrigation, and watch for new white root tips or, conversely, continued mid-day leaf wilting that would signal unresolved rot.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Cross-sections of the crowns show a sharply defined dark-brown core surrounded by mushy, water-soaked tissue; outer crown scales are blackened and slimy; fine feeder roots are sparse and coated in wet, clinging soil; foliage above is wilted with grey-brown, desiccated lower leaves; and the surrounding potting mix appears saturated and poorly aerated. These combined signs point to prolonged soil saturation that has allowed crown-rotting fungi such as Phytophthora or Pythium to colonize the vascular tissue and impede water flow. Immediately discard the two symptomatic plants and any adjacent soil, then raise remaining beds or containers at least 15 cm to enhance drainage; resume irrigation only when the top 2 cm of soil is dry, applying no more than 2.5 cm of water in a single deep watering every 4–5 days; and spread a 2 cm layer of clean straw mulch to reduce surface splashing while permitting airflow. Improve airflow further by spacing crowns 30 cm apart and gently loosening the topsoil to prevent compaction. Over the next seven days, inspect crowns daily for fresh cinnamon-brown streaking, probe soil moisture at 5 cm depth to ensure it is merely damp not wet, and note any new leaf wilting or collapse by mid-afternoon as an early stress indicator.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The roots display dark brown to black streaks along the crown core, many fine feeder roots are absent or water-soaked and translucent, the outer cortex peels away easily leaving thin black strands, foliage directly above is wilted and pale, and overall root mass is sparse compared with healthy reference roots. These combined visuals indicate crown and root rot driven by chronic saturation and poor aeration that favour pathogens such as Pythium or Phytophthora. Elevate and regrade the bed, mixing 5–7 cm of coarse compost and sand into the top 15 cm of soil to boost drainage, and irrigate only when the top 3 cm of soil is dry, supplying 1.5–2 cm of water via drip every four days. Remove and discard any plant whose crown discoloration exceeds 1 cm across, replant survivors at 30 cm spacing for airflow, and spread a 2 cm layer of clean straw mulch to reduce soil splash. Over the next week, inspect each morning for new blackening rings wider than 2 mm at the crown base, probe soil to 4 cm depth to verify it is just moist, and look for the return of firm, white feeder roots and improved leaf turgor as recovery indicators.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The root mass is predominantly tan-to-dark brown rather than creamy white, many fine roots appear water-soaked and stringy, several segments are missing bark and slough easily when handled, and no vigorous white feeder tips are visible, all clustering densely instead of branching outward. These clues point to roots that have been deprived of oxygen in persistently saturated soil, favoring rot-causing organisms such as Phytophthora or Pythium. Immediately lift the planting area by 15 cm (6 in) with well-draining compost-sand mix, and irrigate only when the top 3 cm (1¼ in) of soil is dry, applying no more than 2 cm (¾ in) of water in one session; ensure excess water can exit freely through holes or furrows. Remove and discard the darkest, mushiest roots with sterile shears, and mulch lightly with 2 cm (¾ in) of coarse straw to keep surface moisture even while allowing airflow. Over the next 7 days, probe soil daily at 5 cm (2 in) depth to confirm it is moist but never saturated, inspect crown bases for firm texture rather than soft collapse, and look for emergence of new white root tips near the surface; if any section re-darkens or emits a sour odor, repeat sanitation and shorten irrigation duration further.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The fine feeder roots are sparse, dark brown-to-black, and stringy instead of dense and white, the root cortex is sloughing off leaving bare strands, and the lower crown shows a continuous caramel-coloured band of necrotic tissue that contrasts with the pale central core. Several root tips appear water-soaked and collapsed, and the few remaining healthy roots terminate abruptly at a black margin, all consistent with excess moisture and soil-borne rot fungi. The pattern suggests prolonged saturation that encouraged Phytophthora/Pythium activity. Immediately raise the strawberry bed 20–25 cm with well-drained compost-sand mix, then irrigate only when the top 5 cm of soil feels dry, supplying 2–2.5 cm of water early in the morning so roots dry by dusk. Pull mulch back to leave a 3 cm clear zone around each crown and thin surrounding foliage to create at least 15 cm of airflow between plants, preventing further humidity build-up. Over the next 7 days, probe soil moisture daily at 5 cm depth looking for a moist-but-crumbly texture, gently tug one sacrificed plant every two days to check for emergence of new white root tips, and inspect crowns each morning for any spread of brown lesions or sour odour, recording findings to adjust watering or drainage interventions promptly.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The crown cross-section displays a water-soaked, reddish-brown core bordered by pale yellow tissue, and the adjoining roots are blackened, stringy, and collapsing rather than firm and white. Dark, slimy organic matter is concentrated around the crown base, and fine feeder roots are largely absent, indicating extensive decay limited mostly to lower, constantly moist zones. These visual clues point to root rot likely driven by prolonged soil saturation that favors oomycete pathogens such as Phytophthora or Pythium. Immediately elevate the planting area by at least 20 cm (8 in) with well-drained compost-sand mix, irrigate only in early morning with no more than 2.5 cm (1 in) total water per week, and keep the top 2 cm (¾ in) of soil dry between waterings. Clear and discard all visibly rotted plant material and spread a 3 cm (1¼ in) layer of clean straw mulch to reduce surface splashing while still allowing airflow. Over the next seven days, press the crown gently every other day to confirm it stays firm, probe soil at 5 cm (2 in) depth for excess moisture, and watch for any fresh dark streaks or ooze around the crown that would signal continuing infection.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Dark, water-soaked black tissue surrounds the lower crown and primary roots, while inner crown tissue shows tan to brown necrosis instead of healthy white. Feeder roots are sparse and brittle, with several sections entirely missing or coated in slimy decay. Above-ground, many lower leaves are wilted, curled and papery brown, and surviving foliage is pale and stunted, confirming systemic stress originating from the roots. These combined symptoms point to a soil-borne rot promoted by prolonged saturation and poor drainage. Immediately lift and discard the two worst plants, then amend the bed with 5 cm (2 in) of coarse compost and sand to improve aeration, and irrigate only when the top 4 cm (1.5 in) of soil is dry, delivering 2 cm (¾ in) of water in the early morning so crowns dry quickly. Space remaining plants 30 cm (12 in) apart and mulch lightly with 2 cm (¾ in) of clean straw to reduce splashing, and disinfect tools with a 10 % bleach solution after each use to limit pathogen spread. Over the next seven days, inspect crowns daily for fresh black ooze, probe soil depth with a finger to ensure it is never wetter than moist, and note any new leaf collapse or sour odor; absence of these signs, coupled with the appearance of small white feeder roots at the surface, will indicate recovery.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The plant’s root system is largely dark brown-black, matted and missing fine feeder roots instead of vibrant white fibers. Several crown bases display reddish-brown, water-soaked lesions that extend upward a few millimeters. Mid-tier leaves are chlorotic and curling while top leaves are pale, and many berries are small and shrivelled, signalling impaired water and nutrient transport. The overall canopy is wilting even though stems remain erect, a classic above-ground symptom of root failure. These combined symptoms point to root rot caused by prolonged soil saturation and the probable activity of Phytophthora or Pythium pathogens. Move the plant to a raised bed at least 20 cm (8 in) high with a sandy-loam mix amended with 5 cm (2 in) coarse compost, and irrigate only when the top 2 cm (¾ in) of soil is dry, providing about 1 L (¼ gal) per plant at dawn so moisture reaches 10 cm (4 in) depth and excess drains away. Apply a 3 cm (1¼ in) layer of clean straw mulch held 1 cm (½ in) back from the crown to moderate surface moisture and prevent splash dispersal. Over the next 7 days, look each morning for new white feeder roots emerging at the crown, gently squeeze crowns to confirm they remain firm not mushy, and observe midday leaf posture; improved turgor and absence of new browning indicate recovery.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Several roots exhibit dark brown to nearly black streaks along their length, while adjacent segments are tan, indicating patchy necrosis; the darkest roots are thinnest and shriveled, suggesting tissue collapse. Fine feeder roots are largely absent, and a few tips show a water-soaked translucence, both classic signs of decay progressing from the tip inward. The mixed pattern of healthy pale roots and diseased dark strands points to intermittent saturation, consistent with fungal root-rot complexes that thrive in poorly drained, overly wet media. Improve conditions immediately by raising the strawberry bed 15–20 cm and incorporating 5 cm of coarse compost to increase drainage, then irrigate only when the top 5 cm of soil is dry, applying 2–3 cm of water early in the morning so roots dry by nightfall. Mulch lightly with a 2 cm layer of straw to reduce surface splashing while still allowing airflow, and remove any visibly blackened root sections with sanitized shears before replanting. Over the next 7 days, check soil moisture daily at a 5 cm depth with your finger—water only if it feels dry, inspect newly emerging root tips for a healthy white color every other day, and look for any expansion of dark lesions around the crown to ensure the problem is receding rather than spreading.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Multiple leaves display uniform chocolate-brown desiccation, crispy margins, and downward curl, while only a few inner leaves remain pale green; the crown shows a patch of white, cotton-like fungal mycelium; the root mass is sparse, blackened and slimy instead of firm tan, and several fine roots are missing; overall foliage is wilted and hangs limply rather than standing upright. These combined clues point to chronic water saturation that fostered soil-borne fungi attacking the crown and roots, cutting off water uptake and triggering die-back. Lift the plant, trim away all black or mushy roots with sterile scissors, then replant in a raised bed or pot filled with a mix amended to at least 30 % coarse sand or perlite for drainage, setting the crown no deeper than 1 cm below the surface; irrigate with about 2.5 cm (1 in) of water every 4–5 days, allowing the top 2 cm of soil to dry between soakings. Improve airflow by spacing plants 30 cm (12 in) apart and clearing dead leaves, and lay a 2 cm layer of clean straw mulch to prevent splashing without trapping moisture against the crown. Over the next seven days, visually check the crown daily for any new white mold or dark soft spots, probe the top 2 cm of soil each morning to confirm it dries within 48 h, and watch emerging leaves for firmness and uniform green color—any renewed wilting or browning signals persistent rot that needs immediate root inspection.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The plant shows widespread bronze-brown necrosis on older and mid-aged leaves, blackened petiole bases, a dull, wilted canopy that droops despite intact midribs, and thin, dark, stringy roots with almost no white feeder roots visible. These visual cues point to roots that have decayed from prolonged saturation, limiting water uptake and driving the top-down collapse characteristic of root-rot pathogens favored by poorly drained, anaerobic soil. Immediately lift the crown and replant in a raised bed or pot with a free-draining mix containing at least 40 % coarse perlite, ensuring the crown sits 1 cm above the medium surface; irrigate only when the top 3 cm of mix are dry, delivering about 2 cm of water evenly once every 4–5 days instead of daily soaking. Improve airflow by spacing neighboring plants 25 cm apart and mulch with a 2 cm layer of clean straw to keep the upper roots cool while preventing surface puddling. Over the next 7 days, check that new roots emerging near the crown are creamy-white rather than brown, confirm soil moisture reaches but does not exceed field capacity at 10 cm depth using a finger or moisture probe, and inspect the lowest leaves each morning for recovery of turgor; absence of further leaf browning and the appearance of fresh white root tips will indicate successful remediation.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The majority of the fine feeder roots appear dark-brown to nearly black rather than cream-white, several thicker roots are stringy and collapse when pinched, there is a wet, muddy film sticking to the root ball, and the surrounding planting bed looks compacted with standing-moisture puddling in the background. These visible symptoms point to oxygen starvation and opportunistic water-mold infection that thrive in chronically saturated soil. Immediately lift the plant 3–4 cm higher in the bed or mound fresh, well-draining mix (40 % coarse sand, 60 % compost) under the crown, and restrict irrigation to one deep soak of 2.5 cm (1 in) water only when the top 5 cm of soil feels dry. Pull back existing mulch, then reapply a thinner 2 cm layer of loose straw to keep the crown aerated, and create 20 cm spacing between plants to improve airflow. Over the next 7 days, probe soil moisture daily at 5 cm depth; healthy readings should be moist but not smeary, inspect roots at the soil surface for emergence of new white tips, and watch foliage at midday for loss of wilting or yellowing—any renewed wilt despite drier soil signals additional drainage work is needed.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The exposed crown shows a caramel-brown core instead of the normal creamy white, surrounding root tissues are dark brown and water-soaked, the outer cortex is sloughing off in strings, and fine feeder roots are largely absent, all confined to the lower 3–4 cm of the plant. These discolorations and tissue collapses visually indicate prolonged saturation that favored soil-borne rot organisms attacking the crown and primary roots. Lift beds or containers to 20–25 cm height, and irrigate only when the top 5 cm of soil is dry, applying roughly 2.5 cm of water early morning so excess drains by midday. Incorporate coarse compost or sand to a depth of 15 cm to improve percolation, and add a 3 cm layer of loose straw mulch to keep surfaces aerated while preventing splashing. Over the next 7 days, slice one sacrificed plant every other day to confirm crowns remain creamy white, probe soil with a finger to ensure it dries to the second knuckle between waterings, and look for the emergence of new bright-white root tips at the bed’s edge as a sign of recovery.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The main root axis shows elongated black‐brown streaks that alternate with small patches of lighter tissue, the surface appears shriveled rather than firm, the fine feeder roots are sparse and many are missing or reduced to brittle dark threads, and the remaining laterals display a dry necrotic tip rather than white growing points. Such localized necrosis and loss of feeders usually indicates rot that progressed after prolonged saturation, encouraging soil-borne pathogens to invade weakened root tissue. Immediately improve drainage by raising the bed or container by 20 cm and watering only when the top 2.5 cm (1 in) of soil is dry, delivering no more than 2 cm (¾ in) of water per irrigation and allowing it to percolate fully; gently loosen soil around crowns to a depth of 8 cm (3 in) to enhance aeration; and apply a 2 cm (¾ in) layer of coarse straw mulch to keep surface moisture even without staying wet. Sanitize all cutting tools with a 10 % bleach solution for 60 seconds before touching other plants and discard visibly blackened root fragments to reduce inoculum. Over the next seven days, inspect the root zone every morning for appearance of new white root tips along the lighter sections, press the soil surface to confirm it feels just slightly damp rather than wet, and slice one suspect root every two days to verify the internal core remains cream rather than turning brown. Also watch for any new blackening along previously healthy tan zones and note any sour or sulfur odor from the root area, adjusting watering frequency downward if these signs reappear.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The central plant shows numerous pale-brown, papery leaves collapsed around the crown, and several petioles are shriveled and hanging limply rather than upright. The exposed root mat is dark, stringy and lacks the bright white feeder roots seen in healthy strawberries, while the surrounding soil appears water-saturated and compacted. A few neighboring plants remain green, suggesting the damage is localized to spots where excess moisture pooled. These clues together point to roots suffocating in stagnant water and subsequent infection by soil-borne rot fungi. Raise the bed or add 8–10 cm (3–4 in) of coarse composted bark to improve drainage, and irrigate only when the top 2 cm (¾ in) of soil are dry, applying about 2 cm (¾ in) of water early in the morning so foliage dries quickly. Pull out and discard any plants whose crowns are already soft and brown, then lay a 3 cm (1 in) layer of clean straw mulch to keep surface moisture even without puddling. Over the next seven days, visually inspect midday leaf stance for wilting, gently tug plants to confirm firm crown attachment, and scrape a few roots every other day to verify new white tips are emerging rather than continuing to blacken.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The root mass shows extensive charcoal-black and dark brown discoloration, indicating necrotic tissue, while several strands are tan-yellow and hollow where cortex has sloughed away. Many fine feeder roots are missing or appear slimy and water-soaked, and the remaining roots are brittle and kinked rather than firm and turgid. This pattern, concentrated across most of the system rather than a single segment, is consistent with prolonged saturation and opportunistic fungi that thrive in low-oxygen substrate. Remove all visibly black or mushy roots and replant the crown in a raised bed or container at least 15 cm (6 in) above surrounding grade, filled with a well-draining mix containing 30 % coarse compost and 20 % perlite. Irrigate to a depth of 2.5 cm (1 in) only when the top 5 cm (2 in) of soil feels dry, then allow full drainage; avoid late-evening watering. Add a 2 cm (¾ in) layer of clean straw mulch to moderate moisture swings and keep the crown dry, and maintain 30 cm (12 in) spacing to promote airflow around the base. Over the next 7 days, inspect the soil daily with a finger probe to ensure it is moist but never soggy, look for the emergence of new white feeder roots at the crown, and check for any fresh darkening or sour odor that would signal continued rot progression.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The majority of primary roots are dark brown-to-black and water-soaked, while only a few thin tips remain light tan, indicating extensive tissue decay; many feeder roots are missing, leaving a sparse, uneven root system; the crown tissue directly above the roots shows a glossy, darkened ring suggestive of rot progression; foliage is stunted with slight yellowing at the margins, contrasting with the necrotic roots. These clues point to anaerobic, water-logged soil that has favored soil-borne fungi such as Phytophthora or Pythium. Immediately raise the planting bed 20 cm (8 in) and mix in coarse compost or 5 cm (2 in) of washed sand to improve drainage; irrigate no more than 2.5 cm (1 in) every 5–7 days, allowing the top 5 cm (2 in) of soil to dry between waterings; remove and dispose of any plants showing similar black roots and apply a 3 cm (1.2 in) layer of straw mulch around, but not touching, the crown to stabilize moisture without trapping excess water. Over the next seven days, check soil moisture daily by inserting a finger to 5 cm depth—soil should feel just slightly damp, not sticky; gently lift one or two plants to confirm new white root tips are appearing rather than blackening; and observe midday leaf posture—leaves should remain upright and turgid, not flagging, as an early sign the root zone is recovering.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Visible clues include a continuous dark brown-to-black band running along the main root axis, a sharp orange-to-black demarcation line between living and necrotic tissue, and widespread loss of fine white feeder roots leaving only a thin, broom-stick core. Smaller laterals are shriveled and brittle, and the surface of the darker zones appears water-soaked and slightly glossy, suggesting prolonged saturation. Taken together, the pattern is typical of root decay initiated by waterlogged soil that promotes Phytophthora- or Pythium-type pathogens. Improve conditions immediately by raising the strawberry bed 15 cm and blending 5 cm of coarse composted bark into the top 20 cm to increase drainage; thereafter irrigate only when the upper 2.5 cm of soil is dry, applying roughly 2 cm of water in the early morning every 3–4 days. Pull mulch back 3 cm from each crown and thin neighboring plants to maintain at least 25 cm of airflow space between leaves. Using a sterilized blade, trim off obviously rotten roots and discard them away from the plot, sanitizing tools in a 10 % bleach solution for one minute between plants. For the next seven days, inspect crowns daily for fresh blackening or a sour odor, insert a finger at 5 cm depth to ensure soil feels moist rather than soggy, and look for the appearance of firm white rootlets as an early sign of recovery.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Fine feeder roots are missing and the remaining roots show a uniform cinnamon-brown discoloration instead of the normal creamy white, while the cortex peels away easily exposing dark strands. Several roots are water-soaked and slightly slimy, and the browning extends upward toward the crown, which is beginning to constrict. Aboveground, the attached leaves are wilted and dull green despite having adequate leaf area, indicating impaired water uptake from below. These combined symptoms point to prolonged saturation and poor soil aeration allowing root-rot pathogens to colonize damaged tissue. Immediately raise the strawberry bed or container by at least 15 cm and mix in 20 % coarse sand or perlite to improve drainage, then irrigate only in the early morning, applying 2 cm of water once every 4 days and ensuring the top 3 cm of soil dries between waterings; discard severely rotted plants and disinfect pruning tools in 10 % bleach for 30 seconds. Mulch lightly (1 cm) with clean straw to keep soil splash off crowns while still allowing evaporation, and thin surrounding foliage so that a 10 cm air gap exists between neighboring plants for faster drying. Over the next 7 days, lift one plant gently every second day to verify new white feeder roots are forming, inspect the soil surface daily for standing moisture lasting more than 4 hours after irrigation, and check midday leaf turgor; any recurrence of root browning, persistent puddling, or ongoing wilting signals the need for further drainage correction.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The main structural roots are extensively dark brown-black, many fine feeder roots are absent or reduced to thin wiry strands, the crown base shows soft tan-to-brown streaking, and several lower leaf petioles are yellowed and wilted—all classic visual indicators of rotting roots rather than healthy white tissue. These patterns point to prolonged saturation and poor drainage that favor soilborne fungi such as Phytophthora or Pythium, which invade and collapse the root cortex. Immediately lift surviving plants onto a 20 cm-high (≈8 in) raised ridge or container filled with a well-aerated mix containing at least 30 % coarse compost or perlite, and irrigate only when the top 5 cm (2 in) of soil is dry, supplying about 2.5 cm (1 in) of water per week in one deep morning soak. Remove and discard all visibly rotted roots and sanitize cutting tools with 10 % bleach solution for 1 minute before moving to healthy plants. Over the next seven days, check soil moisture daily by finger to the 5 cm depth, inspect new root tips every other day for bright white growth rather than brown collapse, and watch leaves each morning for fresh wilting or crown browning that would signal ongoing infection or waterlogging.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The primary roots are uniformly dark reddish-brown rather than creamy white, many fine feeder roots are missing or appear stringy and decomposed, and the crown-root junction shows a water-soaked, slightly blackened ring, all indicating tissue death starting from the tips upward. These colors, loss of turgidity, and the general mushiness confined to below-ground tissue point to waterlogging that favors Phytophthora/Pythium infection and subsequent root rot. Lift affected plants, amend the bed with 30 % coarse sand or composted bark and raise it 20–25 cm to improve drainage, and limit irrigation to 2 cm of water applied in the early morning only when the top 3 cm of soil feels dry (about every 4–5 days in warm weather). Apply a 4 cm layer of clean straw mulch around—but not touching—the crown to reduce soil splash and keep surface moisture even. Over the next 7 days, visually inspect newly exposed crowns for fresh brown lesions, gently tug plants to feel for firm versus slipping roots, and insert a finger or moisture probe daily to ensure soil reaches slight dryness at 3 cm depth before the next watering.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The crown base shows a dark brown-black band and slight collapse, many fine roots are missing, surviving roots are tan to black instead of creamy white, and several strands appear water-soaked and brittle, all indicating extensive decay concentrated closest to the crown. Such discoloration and tissue breakdown are consistent with fungal root rot driven by prolonged saturation and poor oxygen around the root zone. Immediately improve drainage by raising the planting row or container mix at least 15 cm (6 in) above surrounding soil and incorporate 30 % coarse compost or perlite to promote aeration; thereafter water no more than 2 cm (¾ in) every 4–5 days, allowing the top 3 cm (1¼ in) to dry before the next irrigation. Lay a 2–3 cm (1 in) layer of clean straw mulch around but not touching the crown to reduce surface splashing and stabilize moisture, and thin surrounding foliage to create 10–15 cm (4–6 in) of open space between plants for better airflow. Over the next week, gently tug one or two plants every other day to feel for firmer anchorage, probe soil at 5 cm depth to ensure it is moist but not wet, and look for emergence of new white feeder root tips or absence of further crown darkening; if any section remains mushy or begins to emit a sour odor, remove and discard those plants promptly to limit spread.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The lower crown shows a broad orange-brown band of necrotic tissue, the surface looks water-soaked and slightly mushy, most fine roots are dark and brittle instead of white and fibrous, and only a few pale new shoots remain on top while the adjacent soil appears heavy and compacted. These visual clues point to prolonged saturation that suffocated roots and encouraged soil-borne rot organisms, likely precipitated by poor drainage and over-irrigation. Immediately raise the planting area by at least 15 cm (6 in) with well-drained compost-sand mix, and irrigate only when the top 3 cm (1 in) of soil are dry, delivering no more than 2 cm (¾ in) of water early in the morning. Remove and discard the affected crown and any adjacent debris, then space replacements 30 cm (12 in) apart to boost airflow and surface drying. Mulch lightly with 2 cm (¾ in) of coarse straw to keep splashing down while still allowing evaporation. Over the next seven days, feel the soil at 3 cm depth each morning to ensure it stays just moist, inspect crowns for firmness rather than softness, and look for emergence of new white feeder roots at the crown edge; absence of these or any spread of discoloration signals further intervention is needed.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The central crown tissue is discolored to a vivid orange-brown and appears water-soaked, the pith is hollowed out forming a dark cavity, fine feeder roots are largely absent or blackened, and surrounding soil is compact and damp, indicating prolonged saturation. These visual signs point to fungal root rot (likely Phytophthora/Pythium) triggered by poorly drained, oxygen-deficient conditions. Immediately lift the plant and amend the bed by incorporating 5–7 cm (2–3 in) of coarse compost and sand into the top 15 cm (6 in) of soil to improve drainage, then replant on a 10–12 cm (4–5 in) high ridge or raised row; water only when the top 5 cm (2 in) of soil is dry, delivering about 1.5 cm (0.6 in) of water early in the morning once every 3–4 days rather than daily. Remove and discard the worst-affected roots, sterilize pruning tools with 70 % alcohol for 30 seconds, and mulch lightly (2 cm/0.8 in) with straw to moderate moisture swings and keep crowns dry. Over the next 7 days, inspect crowns daily for firmness (they should resist gentle thumb pressure), look for emergence of new white root tips at the soil surface, and use a finger probe to confirm that soil at 5 cm depth stays moist but never water-logged; also note any fresh orange ooze or foul odor, as persistence would signal lingering rot and the need for further drainage corrections.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The inner crown tissue is distinctly orange-brown and water-soaked, the outer roots are blackened and brittle, fine feeder roots are largely absent, and there is a sharp transition from healthy pale stem to necrotic base, all indicating active rot concentrated at soil level. These patterns point to water-logged, low-oxygen conditions that favor soil-borne fungi such as Phytophthora or Pythium attacking the crown and primary roots. Immediately lift and discard the symptomatic plant, then fork the bed to a 20 cm depth to improve drainage, and irrigate remaining plants only when the top 3 cm of soil is dry, delivering about 1 L per plant in the early morning so excess moisture can evaporate. Mound or ridge rows to raise crowns 5–7 cm above surrounding soil and spread a 2 cm layer of coarse straw mulch to keep splashing soil away while still allowing air flow. Over the next seven days, probe soil moisture daily at 5 cm depth to verify it dries within 24 h of watering, inspect crown bases for any new orange or black discoloration, and note any wilting or leaf yellowing during midday as early signs requiring further removal or bed modification.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Roots show dark brown to nearly black discoloration, stringy texture, and sloughing outer layers, while interior crown tissue appears mushy yellow-tan rather than crisp white; fine feeder roots are sparse and many tips are missing, and potting mix looks water-logged with shiny perlite floating on the surface. These clues point to prolonged saturation and poor oxygen leading to pathogen proliferation that decomposes cortical root tissue. Immediately lift surviving crowns, trim off all soft or black roots with sterile shears, and replant in a 15–20 cm-high raised bed or container filled with a mix of 60 % composted bark, 30 % perlite, and 10 % sharp sand for rapid drainage. Irrigate only when the top 2 cm of soil are dry, applying 250 ml of water per plant each time and allowing it to percolate to a depth of about 5 cm, then withhold further water until that layer again dries. Mulch lightly with 1 cm of clean straw to reduce surface evaporation without trapping excess moisture, and space plants so that leaves of neighboring crowns remain at least 10 cm apart to improve airflow. Sterilize benches, tools, and discarded soil with a 10 % bleach solution to prevent re-infection, and discard any crowns showing a fermented odor or hollow centers. Over the next seven days, check daily for new firm white root tips emerging from trimmed areas, inspect the crown by gentle pinch for any renewed softness, and use a finger or moisture meter at 2 cm depth morning and evening to confirm soil never stays saturated for more than six hours.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The exposed root mass is uniformly dark brown and lacks the pale white feeder roots typical of healthy strawberries, while several strands appear slick and matted, suggesting rot rather than healthy fibrous texture. In the background, wilted, papery-brown leaves lie flat on the soil surface, and the surrounding mix looks water-logged and compacted, both reinforcing excessive moisture. These visual clues point to oxygen-starved roots likely caused by persistent saturation and poor drainage in the container. Immediately lift the plant, trim off any soft or blackened roots with sterile scissors, then replant in fresh, well-draining mix composed of 60 % peat-free compost, 30 % coarse perlite, 10 % pine bark, filling to leave the crown 1 cm above soil level; water once to a depth of 10 cm (about 500 ml for a 20 cm pot), then allow the top 2 cm to dry before the next irrigation. Elevate the container on spacers and pierce four 6 mm side holes 2 cm above the base to improve airflow and drainage; add a 1 cm layer of coarse mulch to discourage surface moisture retention. Over the next week, check daily that the soil surface is dry to the touch at 2 cm depth, inspect new root tips for creamy white coloration when gently teased, and watch for upright, turgid new leaf growth indicating recovery.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The crown section on the left displays dark cinnamon-brown vascular streaking, water-soaked tissue and partial collapse, while the comparison section on the right remains uniformly cream-yellow and firm. The continuous discoloration along the central vascular bundle suggests internal decay typical of root-rot organisms favored by saturated, low-oxygen soils. Likely cause is prolonged over-irrigation that encouraged Phytophthora/Pythium entry through fine roots. Reduce watering to 2 cm (¾ in) per application every 5 days, deliver it at dawn so crowns dry by midday, and elevate beds or incorporate 5–7 cm (2–3 in) of coarse pine-bark compost to improve drainage and airflow. Remove and discard any plant whose crown shows brown streaking longer than 2 cm, sanitizing cutting tools for 30 seconds in 10 % bleach between plants. For the next 7 days, check soil 5 cm deep each morning—delay irrigation if it smears on fingers, inspect crown bases nightly for new brown lesions >1 cm, and note mid-afternoon leaf turgor; wilting with dry soil is acceptable, but wilting while soil is wet signals ongoing infection.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Multiple roots are jet-black, water-soaked, and collapsing while adjoining roots remain tan and firm, the discoloration is concentrated closest to the crown, and the crown base shows a dull reddish-brown band, all indicating progressive tissue decay. The sharp contrast between necrotic and healthy roots, combined with the matted, slimy texture of the blackened mass, points to root rot triggered by chronic saturation and poor soil aeration that favor water-mold pathogens. Immediately lift the plant, trim off all black mushy roots with sterile shears, and replant in a raised bed or container filled with a sandy loam amended with 30 % coarse compost to increase drainage depth to at least 20 cm. Irrigate only when the upper 5 cm of soil is dry, supplying roughly 2 cm of water in one early-morning soak every 3–4 days rather than daily misting, and keep mulch at a thin 2 cm layer to discourage surface moisture buildup. Improve airflow by spacing plants 30 cm apart and removing any weeds or debris that trap humidity around the crown. Over the next 7 days, check daily for emergence of new white root tips at the soil line, look for any spreading browning on the crown surface, and monitor soil moisture with a finger test to be sure it never stays saturated more than 12 hours. If new roots stay white, crown tissue remains firm, and soil drains within 30 minutes after watering, recovery is on track.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Visible clues include several primary roots turned dark brown to nearly black, patches of slimy decay at the crown–root junction, an overall reduction of fine feeder roots, multiple roots that appear thin and brittle instead of plump, a few isolated healthy white roots indicating uneven damage, and localized dark lesions spreading upward toward the base of the stolon. The pattern and discoloration suggest prolonged saturation and subsequent infection by soil-borne water-molds that thrive in low-oxygen conditions. Remedy the environment by raising the planting bed 15–20 cm and mixing in coarse compost or 1–2 cm of sharp sand per 10 cm of soil to enhance drainage, then irrigate only when the top 5 cm of soil feels dry—roughly 2 cm of water every 4–5 days instead of daily surface sprinkling. Add a 3 cm layer of clean straw mulch to reduce surface evaporation peaks while still allowing airflow, and keep plant rows spaced at least 30 cm apart to promote quick leaf and crown drying. Over the next seven days, gently tug and inspect the crown each morning for firmness rather than soft collapse, scrape a few roots every other day to verify that new growth remains white, and press a finger into the soil at 5 cm depth daily to ensure it stays moist but not waterlogged (no pooling or glistening film).

Diagnosis: root_rot. Most fine roots are uniformly black and shriveled instead of light tan, the root surface looks water-soaked and dull, many lateral branches are missing, and there is a sharp boundary where a still-pale crown meets the dark necrotic roots, all of which visually signal extensive decay. These symptoms are consistent with roots suffocating in saturated soil and becoming infected by water-loving pathogens such as Phytophthora or Pythium. Raise the bed 15–20 cm and mix in a 5 cm layer of coarse compost to improve drainage, then irrigate only when the top 2 cm of soil is dry, applying about 1 L per plant by drip so moisture penetrates no deeper than 8 cm. Remove and discard the most damaged plants and disinfect cutting tools with 70 % alcohol after each cut; add a 3 cm straw mulch to limit soil splash and keep crowns drier. Over the next 7 days, visually confirm that new white feeder roots appear near the crown, probe soil daily at 5 cm depth to be sure it feels just slightly moist rather than wet, and watch for leaves regaining turgor and brighter green color as early recovery indicators.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Multiple roots display dark brown to black discoloration, shriveling, and loss of cortical tissue, while a few remaining strands are pale and brittle; several roots are collapsed and water-soaked in appearance; the crown base shows a necrotic band immediately below an intact pale section; and fine feeder roots are largely absent. These visible patterns indicate rot advancing upward from the root zone, most often triggered by prolonged saturation and opportunistic soil fungi attacking oxygen-deprived tissues. Immediately improve drainage by raising the bed or container 20 cm and incorporating coarse compost or perlite to 30 cm depth; irrigate only when the top 2.5 cm of soil is dry, delivering about 1 cm of water early in the morning every 3–4 days; and apply a 5 cm layer of clean straw mulch to reduce surface evaporation while keeping crowns dry. Ensure unobstructed airflow by trimming neighboring vegetation to maintain at least 15 cm clearance around the plant and sanitize tools after each cut. Over the next 7 days, inspect daily for emergence of firm, white feeder roots at the crown, gently pinch the crown to confirm it remains firm rather than mushy, and note any spread of dark lesions or sour odor; record findings to adjust irrigation frequency promptly.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Multiple roots exhibit dark brown to nearly black streaks radiating from the crown, while adjacent portions that should be cream-tan are noticeably water-soaked and translucent. Fine feeder roots are largely absent or collapsed, leaving a sparse, stringy network that contrasts with the thicker, discolored primary roots. Several root tips display a mushy texture and slight sheen, indicating tissue breakdown, and the discoloration is most intense within the upper 3–4 cm of the crown zone. These visual cues point to prolonged saturation and poor aeration that favor pathogenic fungi responsible for root rot. Immediately lift plants onto ridged beds or mounds raised at least 15 cm, reduce irrigation to 1 cm of water every 4 days only when the top 2 cm of soil feels dry, and mix in 30 % coarse compost or sand to improve drainage around the root zone. Remove and discard the most severely affected crowns and sterilize tools with 70 % alcohol between cuts to limit spread. Over the next 7 days, probe soil at 5 cm depth each morning to ensure it crumbles rather than smears, visually inspect new root tips for a return to creamy white coloration, and check daily for any fresh wilting or blackening at the crown base so adjustments can be made promptly.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The root system shows several medium-brown strands intermingled with otherwise tan roots, a pinkish-darkened crown base, and a few roots appearing limp rather than crisp, all confined to the top 3 cm of soil, while the soil itself looks heavy and moisture-laden without visible perlite or coarse particles. These discolorations and textural changes point to early root rot likely triggered by prolonged saturation and poor aeration around the crown. Immediately lift the plant, amend the bed with 4 cm of coarse composted bark or perlite to improve drainage, then replant so the crown sits 1 cm above the final soil surface; thereafter irrigate only when the top 2 cm of soil are dry, delivering roughly 1 cm of water in the early morning every 3–4 days. Space surrounding plants at least 25 cm apart and gently rake the surface to keep a loose top layer that dries quickly, enhancing airflow. Over the next 7 days, inspect daily for newly emerging white root tips (sign of recovery), check that no further brown mush forms at the crown, and sniff the soil for any sour odor that would indicate lingering anaerobic conditions.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Several main roots show patchy light-tan to dark-brown discoloration, some segments are almost black, cortex tissue is sloughing off exposing fibrous strands, and fine feeder roots are largely absent, indicating progressive decay. The mixture of water-soaked and dried lesions along with adhering heavy soil suggests prolonged saturation that favors soil-borne pathogens, most likely Phytophthora or Pythium, attacking oxygen-starved tissue. Immediately lift or replant into a raised bed 15–20 cm high or a container with at least 30 % coarse compost and perlite to improve drainage, and irrigate only 1–2 cm of water every 3–4 days early morning so the root zone dries to the first 5 cm before the next watering. Apply 2–3 cm of loose straw mulch around but not touching the crown to reduce splash while maintaining airflow, and remove all visibly blackened roots with sanitized shears before replanting. Over the next 7 days, verify that soil at 5 cm depth feels barely moist rather than wet each morning, inspect the crown base every two days for emergence of firm white root tips rather than additional browning, and watch midday foliage for reduced wilting or yellowing as an indicator the remaining roots are recovering.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Multiple rows show large patches of completely blighted or missing plants, with brown, dry foliage and collapsed crowns, while adjacent rows remain green; the dead plants are concentrated in slight depressions, and the surrounding soil appears compacted and straw-covered yet still lighter in tone than healthy rows, suggesting poor moisture dispersion; scattered survivors display stunting and dull, bronze leaves rather than the firm, glossy green of healthy canopies. Such patchy die-off in low sections and crown collapse are typical of root rot triggered by prolonged soil saturation that suffocates roots and encourages pathogens. Immediately raise affected beds by 20–25 cm and slope shoulders outward so excess water runs off; irrigate only when the top 5 cm of soil is dry, delivering about 2.5 cm of water in the early morning once every 5–7 days instead of daily surface sprinkling; remove and destroy visibly dead plants, then top-dress rows with 3–4 cm of coarse compost to improve drainage and root aeration. Over the next week, probe soil at 5 cm depth each morning to confirm it dries to a crumbly texture within 24 h of irrigation, inspect crowns for renewed firmness and white interior tissue rather than brown mush, and note whether new leaves emerge with a healthy green sheen along row edges; photograph and compare these checks on days 1, 4, and 7 to verify stabilization or spread.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Several plants in the center strip show foliage that is wilted and lying flat against the straw while the bordering plants stand upright, indicating localized collapse; leaves in the affected zone are a dull gray-green with scattered reddish-brown blotches, unlike the uniformly dark green leaves nearby; plant density is visibly thinner with bare soil patches exposed, and some flowers are present on limp, weak pedicels, all consistent with root impairment; the soil just beneath the straw in the sick band appears darker and wetter than adjacent areas, hinting at poor drainage. These visual patterns point to waterlogged roots that have likely been invaded by rot pathogens such as Phytophthora or Pythium thriving in saturated pockets. Immediately fork in 3–4 cm of coarse compost or sand along the affected 30 cm strip to lift and aerate the root zone, and limit irrigation to 2 cm (¾ in) of water applied every 4–5 days in the early morning so soil dries to 5 cm depth by nightfall; if crowns feel mushy, remove and discard entire plants, then re-mulch with a 2 cm layer of clean, loose straw to prevent surface sealing. Over the next week, check each morning for (1) new wilting or discoloration in neighboring plants, (2) soil moisture by inserting a finger 5 cm deep— it should feel only slightly damp, not wet— and (3) crown firmness, discarding any plants whose crowns turn soft or emit a sour odor. Consistent airflow, drier soil, and prompt sanitation should arrest further spread.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Visible indications include (1) widespread tan-to-cinnamon discoloration of primary roots instead of healthy creamy white, (2) missing or shriveled lateral feeder roots giving a sparse, broom-like appearance, (3) several main roots look hollow or stringy where cortical tissue has sloughed off, and (4) fine soil particles cling to soft, water-soaked sections near the crown. These symptoms point to roots suffocated and subsequently invaded by water-loving fungi/oomycetes that thrive in chronically wet, poorly drained soil. Immediately improve drainage by raising the strawberry bed 15–20 cm and incorporating a 5 cm layer of coarse compost plus sand to promote percolation; thereafter irrigate only when the top 5 cm of soil is dry, applying no more than 2.5 cm of water early morning once every 4–5 days in warm weather. Remove and discard severely affected plants, taking at least 5 cm of surrounding soil, and sanitize tools with hot water after each plant to limit spread. Over the next seven days, (a) tug gently on remaining plants every second day—firm anchorage indicates new root growth, (b) probe soil twice daily with a finger or moisture meter to ensure the top 5 cm does not stay saturated for more than 6 hours, and (c) inspect any exposed root tips for the return of bright white coloration and absence of sour odor.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The entire root mass is dark brown-to-black rather than creamy white, individual roots appear thin and stringy with sections collapsing when bent, there are almost no fine feeder roots visible, and a few roots show slimy sheen consistent with decay. These visual clues point to water-saturated soil that encouraged fungal pathogens to destroy cortical tissues, leading to classic root rot. Immediately lift remaining plants into a raised bed or mound at least 15 cm (6 in) high and amend with 5 cm (2 in) of coarse compost and sand to improve drainage; thereafter irrigate only when the top 2 cm (¾ in) of soil are dry, delivering roughly 2.5 cm (1 in) of water in the early morning once every 4–5 days. Remove and discard all visibly blackened roots, sanitize tools with 70 % alcohol, and mulch lightly with 2 cm (¾ in) of clean straw to reduce splash and promote airflow around crowns. Over the next seven days, inspect the crown base daily for any fresh dark lesions, gently probe the topsoil to ensure it dries within 24 h of watering, and look for emergence of new white root tips at the edge of the root zone as a sign of recovery.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The exposed root section shows a continuous dark brown cortex contrasted by an orange-brown inner stele, longitudinal cracking along the length, a dry but fibrous texture, and no healthy white feeder roots visible—classic external and internal discoloration consistent with rotting. These color changes and tissue breakdown indicate prolonged excess moisture that likely allowed soil-borne fungi (e.g., Phytophthora/Pythium) to invade and destroy cortical tissue. Immediately improve drainage by raising the planting bed at least 15 cm and incorporating 20 % coarse sand or composted bark into the top 20 cm of soil; irrigate only when the upper 5 cm of soil is dry, delivering about 2 cm of water early morning once every 4 days instead of daily misting. Pull back mulch so it starts 2 cm from the crown and thin surrounding foliage to create a 15 cm air gap between plants, boosting airflow and surface drying. Over the next 7 days, gently excavate one or two plants every other day and inspect whether new feeder roots appear white and firm, push a finger 5 cm into the soil to verify it feels barely moist rather than wet, and note any sour or earthy odor when roots are exposed; absence of smell and return of white roots indicate recovery.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The root mass shows a predominance of tan-to-brown strands with very few bright white feeder roots, several segments are visibly darkened near the crown, and the outer cortex on some roots appears sloughed off, leaving stringy inner fibers; soil clinging to the roots looks dense and water-logged, and the upper crown tissue has a dull, slightly translucent look instead of a crisp green base. These clues point to oxygen-starved roots caused by prolonged saturation and poor drainage that allow rot pathogens to proliferate. Immediately lift the plant onto a mound or raised bed at least 8 cm (3 in) higher than surrounding soil, blend the planting mix 1:1 with coarse compost and perlite to improve porosity, and irrigate only when the top 3 cm (1¼ in) of soil feels dry, applying roughly 250 ml per plant in the early morning. Mulch lightly with 2 cm (¾ in) of clean straw to moderate surface moisture while preserving airflow around the crown, and thin nearby vegetation to create a 20 cm (8 in) air gap for faster surface drying. Over the next 7 days, check daily for emerging white root tips at the edge of the root ball, ensure the soil surface dries within 24 hours of watering, and inspect the crown for any further darkening or soft spots so adjustments can be made promptly.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The fine feeder roots are dark brown to nearly black instead of creamy white, many are water-soaked and stripped of cortex, several thicker roots show tan mushy breaks, crown tissue is ringed with brown lesions, and the foliage above is wilted with yellow margins—together these five visible cues signal advanced root decay. Such widespread discoloration and tissue collapse are most consistent with root-rot fungi flourishing in chronically saturated, poorly aerated soil. Immediately raise the strawberry bed 15–20 cm high and 40 cm wide and limit irrigation to one deep soaking of roughly 2.5 cm every 5–7 days, applied at dawn only after the upper 5 cm of soil feels dry. Mix 2–3 cm of coarse compost or sand into the top 10 cm of soil to boost drainage and airflow, and remove any plants showing more than 50 % blackened roots to cut inoculum pressure. For the next week, probe soil moisture each morning at 5 cm depth; it should feel moist but not wet within two hours of watering. Every other day gently tug a few plants—firm resistance and emerging white root tips denote recovery, whereas looseness signals ongoing rot. Also photograph crown bases daily, checking for new brown rings or water-soaked spots so corrective measures can be intensified promptly.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The excavated plant shows a dark, water-soaked crown center, with many fine roots browned and sloughing, while only a few pale, healthy feeder roots remain; dried, crispy leaves cluster around the crown; and a small, poorly colored berry hangs undersized, indicating impaired uptake. Soil clods adhere densely to the root mass, suggesting persistently wet, poorly drained conditions under the plastic mulch. These visual cues point to root-rot pathogens flourishing in oxygen-starved soil. Immediately reduce irrigation to one deep soaking of roughly 2 cm (≈0.8 in) every 4–5 days instead of light daily watering, and slit the plastic around each plant in a 15 cm (6 in) radius to vent excess moisture and heat. Mound additional soil or compost 10–12 cm (4–5 in) high around rows to raise the crown above standing water and lay a 2 cm (¾ in) layer of clean straw mulch to moderate surface moisture; remove and discard all brown leaves and rotted crowns to improve airflow and sanitation. Over the next 7 days, probe the root zone daily at 5 cm (2 in) depth to ensure it feels only slightly moist, inspect crowns for firmness rather than mushiness, and look for the appearance of new white root tips or upright, turgid new leaves as early signs of recovery.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The crown and upper roots are blackened and water-soaked, many feeder roots are missing or reduced to dark threads, and the transition zone is mushy rather than firm; lower leaves are dried, brown and curling while only the top leaves remain green; green fruits are small with wilted peduncles; a wet stain line sits on the crown indicating prolonged saturation. These features point to root tissues dying from excess moisture that likely allowed Phytophthora/Pythium fungi to colonize the crown. Transplant remaining healthy portions into a raised bed or container filled 20–25 cm deep with a well-drained mix of 40 % coarse sand, 40 % finished compost and 20 % perlite, positioning the crown no deeper than 1 cm below the surface; irrigate in the early morning every 3–4 days, giving 2–3 cm of water only when the top 5 cm of soil is dry; add a 2 cm straw mulch layer around (not touching) the crown to reduce splash and moderate temperature. Over the next 7 days, daily verify that the crown tissue stays firm and light brown rather than soft or black, watch for new white root tips appearing at container drainage holes, and check each noon that leaves remain turgid without mid-day wilt or sour odor—any reversal signals persistent rot requiring further drainage improvement.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The crown cross-sections show honey-brown, water-soaked tissue rather than firm white pith, several roots are dark, stringy and easily pulled off, fine feeder roots are mostly absent, and the outer cortex sloughs away leaving bare stele—all classic indicators of rot starting from the root zone and progressing upward. These visual clues point to prolonged saturation and oxygen deprivation that favor soilborne pathogens such as Phytophthora or Pythium. Immediately improve drainage by raising the planting row 20–25 cm with a 50:50 mix of coarse compost and sandy loam, and water only when the top 3 cm of soil is dry, delivering a single deep soak of about 2.5 cm every 4–5 days in early morning rather than frequent light sprays. Remove and discard the visibly affected plants, dispose of them off-site, and sanitize tools with 10 % bleach solution for one minute before re-use. Over-mulch the row with 5 cm of clean straw to reduce soil splash and maintain even moisture without puddling. For the next seven days, inspect crowns daily for new soft tan lesions or oozing, probe soil at 5 cm depth to confirm it stays moist but not wet, and look for the reappearance of firm white feeder roots at the tips of remaining plants as a sign of recovery.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The main roots are dark brown to nearly black rather than healthy cream, several lateral roots are missing or shriveled, the central stele appears soft and stringy, a faint white cotton-like mycelium sheet is woven between root segments, and the overall bundle shows a matted, water-soaked texture instead of firm fibrous strands. These symptoms point to prolonged saturation and poor oxygen around the crown that encouraged soil-borne fungi responsible for root rot. Immediately lift the bed surface by 20 cm (8 in) with well-draining compost and coarse sand, then irrigate only when the top 3 cm (1 in) of soil is dry, applying roughly 2 cm (¾ in) of water at each event to keep moisture but avoid puddling. Remove and discard the worst-affected plants, rinsing tools in a 10 % bleach solution and spreading a 3 cm (1 in) layer of clean straw mulch to reduce future splash and compaction. Over the next week, visually check that new feeder roots stay light tan, watch for any fresh white fungal webbing near the crown, and confirm that soil at 5 cm (2 in) depth smells earthy rather than sour or anaerobic.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Leaves in several plants show dull purpling and marginal browning, whole canopies in panel D are collapsed, and root masses in panels B and F are black, shriveled and greatly reduced compared with the tan, fibrous roots in panel E; many roots also exhibit a sharp transition from healthy orange to water-soaked black tissue. These patterns point to roots dying from prolonged saturation that favors soil-borne fungi such as Phytophthora/Pythium rather than a foliar nutrient issue. Immediately lift affected crowns, trim away all black, mushy roots, and replant only firm tissue into a raised bed or pot at least 15 cm above surrounding grade filled with a mix containing 20 % perlite for fast drainage; irrigate to a depth of 2 cm no more than every 4 days, skipping any time the top 3 cm feels moist. Add a 5 cm layer of clean straw mulch to keep surface moisture even while still allowing evaporation, and maintain 30 cm spacing between crowns or thin plants to improve airflow around the crown. Over the next 7 days, gently tug each crown daily—resistance indicates roots are regaining hold—, probe the soil to 5 cm to confirm it is only slightly damp before watering, and look for new white feeder roots or fresh green leaves emerging instead of further blackening; dispose of any crowns that become soft or emit foul odor to prevent spread.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Upper foliage shows patchy chlorosis progressing to crisp brown necrosis, while the newest central leaf remains smaller and pale, indicating systemic decline; exposed crowns are water-soaked and chocolate-brown instead of creamy white; fine feeder roots are sparse, brittle and uniformly black; cross-sectioned crowns in panel D reveal tan rings and mushy tissue; potting mix around affected plants looks continually damp with no visible aeration pores. These combined symptoms point to roots suffocating in saturated media, encouraging crown-invading fungi such as Phytophthora or Pythium. Immediately lift trays or beds 5 cm to improve drainage, irrigate only every 2–3 days with 2 cm of water applied early morning so surface dries by night, and incorporate 20 % coarse perlite or pine bark into the top 10 cm of substrate to raise porosity. Remove and discard all visibly black-rooted plants, trim away dead leaves, and sanitize shears in 10 % bleach solution for 1 min between cuts.
