Mulch lightly with 1 cm of clean straw to reduce surface splashing while still allowing airflow. Over the next 7 days, check daily for: 1) soil moisture staying below damp at 2.5 cm depth before the next watering, 2) appearance of firm, white new root tips on any remaining plants when gently teased, and 3) absence of fresh crown browning or foul odor; any plant failing two of these checks should be removed at once.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Visible clues: roots are uniformly dark brown-black and water-soaked, healthy white feeder roots are mostly absent, many strands are thin and shriveled, the crown center is mushy and dark, and several fine tan roots are disconnected and hanging loose. The pattern indicates roots have been starved of oxygen and invaded by moisture-loving fungi that thrive in saturated, poorly drained soil. Action: 1) Replant survivors in a raised bed 20–25 cm higher than the surrounding ground or in containers with a mix containing at least 30 % coarse perlite to increase drainage; 2) irrigate only when the top 3 cm of soil are dry, giving a single 2.5 cm (1 inch) deep watering every 5–7 days instead of daily light sprays; 3) remove all plants with blackened crowns, dispose of them off-site, and disinfect tools in a 10 % bleach solution for 2 minutes, then apply a 3 cm layer of clean straw mulch to keep surface moisture moderate without sealing the soil. Monitoring next 7 days: each morning press a finger 3 cm into the soil to confirm it feels barely moist before watering again; every second day expose one small section of root on a test plant to verify new growth is white and firm, not dark; and observe foliage twice daily for signs of fresh wilting or yellowing that would suggest continuing root failure. Replace or thin any mulch that becomes slimy or emits a sour odor, and promptly discard any additional plants showing new black lesions at the crown to prevent further spread.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The crown cross-section shows a sharp contrast between an orange-brown, water-soaked interior and a black, necrotic outer cortex, while the attached feeder roots are shriveled, dark and matted rather than creamy and fibrous. Several roots have lost their fine rootlets, and the tissue surface looks slippery and collapsed, all indicative of extensive decay rather than mechanical injury. The discoloration is centralized and progressive toward the crown core, suggesting pathogen activity rather than nutrient deficiency. These clues point to root rot triggered by prolonged saturation and poor drainage that favor soil-borne fungi such as Phytophthora or Rhizoctonia. Immediately improve drainage by raising the planting row 15–20 cm and incorporating a 2–3 cm layer of coarse composted bark to increase porosity; water only in the early morning, delivering 1.2–1.5 cm once soil at 5 cm depth feels barely moist, and never allow standing water around crowns. Remove and discard the affected plant with 10 cm of surrounding soil and sanitize tools with 70 % alcohol to prevent spread. Over the next seven days, gently probe 5 cm deep to confirm soil drains within 4 hours of irrigation, lift one random plant daily to verify roots remain white and firm, and inspect exposed crowns each evening for any new amber or black soft spots indicating further rot progression.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The crown cross-section shows tan to cinnamon-brown discoloration with water-soaked margins, the peripheral root tissues are dark and mushy, foliage is wilted and flagging despite intact petioles, leaflets display scorched brown edges and midrib collapse, and the plant as a whole is lying flat with no turgor. Such symptoms collectively point to roots suffocating in chronically wet soil, favoring soil-borne pathogens that destroy vascular tissue and block water movement. 1) Lift remaining rows onto a raised bed or ridge 20–25 cm high and amend with 30 % coarse compost to speed drainage. 2) Shift irrigation to a deeper, less frequent schedule: apply 2.5 cm of water every 4–5 days early morning, avoiding any watering when the top 5 cm of soil is still moist. 3) Remove each visibly affected plant with at least 10 cm of surrounding soil and dispose of it off-site; mulch the cleared spot with 3 cm of clean straw to reduce splashing onto neighboring crowns. Over the next 7 days, slice a sample crown every other day to confirm tissue stays cream-white, probe soil at 5 cm depth daily to verify it is damp rather than saturated, and inspect midday foliage for fresh wilt or darkening that would signal ongoing rot expansion.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The crown shows widespread dark reddish-brown bands encircling the outer cortex, contrasted against a still-yellow interior core, indicating tissue death starting from the outside in. Outer root remnants are black, brittle and partially missing, and the crown tissues appear water-soaked and slightly hollowed, all consistent with decay rather than mechanical injury. Discoloration is irregular but follows the vascular ring, and the surrounding adhering soil is wet and compact, suggesting prolonged moisture at the root zone. These clues point to waterlogged conditions that favor soil-borne fungi (e.g., Phytophthora) attacking the roots and crown. Immediately improve drainage by raising the bed or container 15 cm and watering only every 3–4 days, supplying about 2.5 cm of water each time in the early morning so the top 3 cm of soil dries before nightfall; remove and discard the visibly affected plant and sanitize tools with 70 % alcohol. Add a 5 cm layer of coarse straw or pine-needle mulch, keeping a 2 cm gap around each crown, and thin surrounding foliage to create at least 20 cm of airflow space between plants. Over the next 7 days, inspect daily for any new crowns developing brown streaks at the soil line, gently squeeze remaining crowns for firmness (they should feel solid, not spongy), and note any sour or earthy odor from the root zone as an early sign of recurring rot.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The split crown shows circular reddish-brown necrotic pockets within otherwise cream tissue, the necrosis is centered around vascular rings, fine feeder roots appear sparse and dark, and surrounding soil looks compact and moist, all indicating water-borne decay. Such localized internal browning with root thinning is consistent with fungal root and crown rot encouraged by prolonged saturation and poor aeration. Immediately lift the bed or container by 10–15 cm and incorporate coarse compost or sand through the top 20 cm to improve drainage; thereafter apply no more than 2.5 cm of water every 5–7 days, stopping if the top 2 cm of soil is still damp. Mulch with 5 cm of loose straw, keeping a 3 cm gap around each crown to reduce surface splash and temperature swings, and remove any plants showing more than 50 % crown discoloration to limit inoculum. Over the next week, inspect daily for fresh amber or dark streaks on newly cut crown surfaces, note any wilting of youngest leaves during cool mornings, and gently tug plants every two days to feel for further root loosening or breakage; any worsening of these signs signals the need for further culling or drainage adjustment.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The crown bases show distinct reddish-brown lesions that penetrate into the pith, the outer crown tissue is water-soaked and beginning to slough, root systems are sparse with many dark, brittle roots and only a few white feeder tips, and several lower leaves are wilted or necrotic while new shoots are stunted. This pattern indicates roots have been killed by excess soil moisture, creating anaerobic conditions that favor rot-causing fungi. Immediately cut irrigation back to a single deep watering of 2–3 cm (≈1 in) once every 5–7 days, ensuring the top 2 cm of soil dries before the next cycle; re-plant or mound surviving plants on raised beds 20–25 cm (8–10 in) high and mix in coarse compost or perlite for drainage; remove and discard all visibly rotted plants and sanitize tools with hot water or 70 % alcohol. Lay 5 cm (2 in) of clean straw mulch to limit surface splash and keep crowns slightly elevated, and maintain 30–40 cm (12–16 in) spacing to improve airflow. Over the next week, each morning check soil moisture by inserting a finger to 5 cm depth—soil should feel only slightly damp; every second day gently scrape a small window on two crowns to confirm no expansion of brown tissue; and observe emerging leaves for firm, turgid growth and the appearance of new white root tips when lightly uncovering the root zone.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Exposed root system shows overall dark gray-to-black coloration, missing healthy white feeder tips, noticeable shriveling and collapse of several primary roots, and some areas where the cortex appears sloughed off, all concentrated along the lower 5–8 cm of the crown. These symptoms indicate roots have been deprived of oxygen, most likely from prolonged saturation that encouraged soil-borne rot organisms. Immediately improve drainage by raising beds or containers at least 15 cm and apply irrigation only when the top 3 cm of soil is dry, giving no more than 2 cm (≈0.8 in.) of water per session and allowing water to percolate to a depth of 10 cm; keep foliage dry by watering at the base early in the day. Gently trim away soft, blackened roots with sterilized pruners, dust the cut ends with dry horticultural sand, and replant into fresh, well-aerated mix containing 20 % coarse compost; space plants 30 cm apart to boost airflow. Mulch lightly (1 cm layer) with clean straw to moderate moisture while avoiding direct crown contact. Over the next 7 days, inspect root collars daily for renewed white root tips, feel soil with a finger to ensure it stays moist but never waterlogged, and note any sour or sulfur smells that would signal persistent anaerobic conditions; also watch for improved leaf turgor during midday as a sign of recovery.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The primary roots show patchy dark brown to black bands with a water-soaked sheen, several fine feeder roots are missing or shriveled, the crown base is discolored and slightly sunken, and clods of heavy, compacted soil cling tightly to the root mass, all indicating poor aeration and decay. These symptoms are consistent with fungal root rot developing under chronically saturated, poorly drained conditions that suffocate roots and favor pathogens such as Phytophthora or Pythium. Immediately lower irrigation volume to 2 cm (¾ in) total per week applied in two light applications, raise the bed or container height by at least 15 cm (6 in) to improve drainage, and gently top-dress with 2 cm (¾ in) of coarse composted pine bark to enhance airflow around the crown. Sanitize nearby plant debris, and rinse tools in a 10 % bleach solution before moving to healthy plants to limit spread. Over the next seven days, inspect the crown daily for any further softening or odor, probe soil 5 cm (2 in) deep to confirm it dries to just-moist between waterings, and look for the appearance of firm, white root tips as an early sign of recovery.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Visible clues include cinnamon-brown decay in the crown’s interior, yellow-tan water-soaked margins between healthy and dead tissue, black and stringy feeder roots, slimy cortical sloughing, and surrounding soil that looks consistently wet and compacted. Such a pattern indicates crown and root rot brought on by prolonged saturation and poor drainage that favor soil-borne pathogens like Phytophthora or Pythium. Remove and dispose of severely affected plants and trim off up to 2 cm (¾ in) of discolored crown tissue on borderline cases, disinfecting blades with 70 % alcohol between cuts. Raise the bed 15–20 cm (6–8 in) with coarse compost or sand, then irrigate only when the top 2.5 cm (1 in) of soil has dried, applying no more than 25 mm (1 in) of water per session via drip to keep foliage dry. Add a 2 cm (¾ in) straw mulch layer around crowns to limit splash and improve airflow, and thin runners to maintain at least 20 cm (8 in) spacing. Over the next seven days, inspect daily for fresh wilting or dull, gray-green leaves on adjacent plants, probe soil moisture at 5 cm (2 in) depth each morning to ensure it is only slightly moist, and gently press a few crowns every other day to verify they stay firm and cream-colored rather than soft and brown.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Large sections of the nursery tray show plants collapsed and brown while adjacent foliage remains sparse and patchy, indicating widespread crown failure. A close-up leaf displays dozens of dark brown pinpoint lesions with surrounding chlorosis, consistent with systemic stress from below-ground decay. Exposed roots are black, water-soaked and peel easily, and the sliced crown core is uniformly brown rather than creamy white, confirming internal rot. These signs point to prolonged saturation and poor drainage that favour Phytophthora/Pythium organisms attacking fine roots and crowns. Immediately discard all plants whose crowns are brown for more than 2 cm, bagging them off-site, and disinfect cutting tools for 60 s in a 10 % bleach solution between plants. Reduce irrigation to 0.5 cm of water every 48 h, allowing the upper 2 cm of substrate to dry before re-watering, and raise trays on 15 cm slatted benches while running horizontal airflow fans to keep canopy air speed near 0.3 m s⁻¹. Over the next seven days, each morning inspect crown cross-sections for fresh darkening, perform a gentle tug test for root firmness, and verify that potting mix surface feels dry to 1 cm depth before the next watering; also watch new leaf tips for turgor recovery and absence of additional black spots.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Visible evidence includes dark-brown, water-soaked tissue overlaid by a dense white mycelial web, clustered black perithecia protruding from the surface, pale acervuli packed with conidia, and microscope imagery of blunt-ended cylindrical spores consistent with Colletotrichum gloeosporioides. These structures point to a fungal root and crown infection fostered by prolonged soil saturation and limited oxygen around the roots. 1) Reduce irrigation to a single deep watering of 2–3 cm (0.8–1.2 in) every 5 days, applied early morning so the upper 5 cm of soil dries by nightfall. 2) Carefully remove and discard visibly rotted roots and the surrounding 5 cm (2 in) of soil, then replant in raised beds at least 15 cm (6 in) high to improve drainage. 3) Apply a loose 4 cm (1.5 in) layer of clean straw mulch to minimize soil splash and maintain moderate moisture without sealing the surface. Over the next 7 days, visually check the crown bases daily for new black perithecia or salmon-pink spore ooze, probe soil at 5 cm depth to keep it just moist but never glossy-wet, and note any expansion of white mycelial mats on exposed roots or mulch surfaces.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Dark-brown, water-soaked tissue is clearly visible in the split crown and upper roots, several whole plants are stunted and pale beside normal green neighbors, many outer leaves are wilted and crisp while inner petioles collapse, and entire rows show patchy die-back with dried runners and foliage lying flat on the plastic mulch. Such crown and root discoloration combined with uneven plant vigor strongly indicates soil-borne rot organisms thriving in persistently wet, poorly drained zones under the plastic. 1) Reduce irrigation to 2 cm (0.8 in) per application, delivered every 4–5 days at dawn, and keep emitters calibrated so water penetrates no deeper than 15 cm (6 in). 2) Improve drainage by cutting shallow (5 cm) side slits in the plastic and adding a 3 cm layer of coarse straw between rows to wick excess moisture. 3) Remove and discard all visibly rotted crowns plus surrounding soil within a 10 cm radius to limit inoculum spread. For the next seven days, check daily at noon that soil at 5 cm depth feels only slightly moist, record any new leaf wilt within two hours of sunrise, and inspect the crown base of three random plants each evening for fresh brown streaking; absence of these signs will confirm recovery.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The pictured strawberry shows extensive upper canopy wilt with entire leaves desiccated to a light-brown, a dull brown discoloration running through the longitudinally sliced crown tissue, and several attached roots that appear darkened and water-soaked near their junction with the crown; additionally, a separate image panel displays marbled reddish-brown internal lesions and oospore-like round bodies inside root tissues. These concurrent brown, water-soaked crown cores and necrotic root collars strongly indicate root rot caused by Phytophthora or related soilborne pathogens that thrive in saturated media. Immediately improve drainage by pulling back mulch and cultivating a 5–7 cm (2–3 in) berm around each plant to elevate crowns, then apply 2–3 cm (¾–1 in) of coarse composted pine bark to increase porosity; irrigate only every 3–4 days, delivering 1.5 cm (½ in) of water each time in early morning so soil dries by nightfall. Thin the bed to maintain at least 25 cm (10 in) airflow gaps between plants and remove any dead foliage or crowns, bagging and discarding them off-site to reduce inoculum. Over the next 7 days, inspect daily for new wilting despite moist soil, note any fresh brown streaks inside sampled crown slices, and probe soil 10 cm (4 in) deep to verify it is moist but never saturated after 24 h; also watch for emergence of white mycelial fans at the soil surface as an early sign of renewed pathogen activity.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The plant shows widespread mid-brown to dark, papery leaf tissue with a downward curl, several leaves entirely necrotic and hanging limp; the crown appears shriveled and darkened; and the exposed root mass is sparse, blackish in sections, and lacking the usual white feeder roots. Such uniform collapse of foliage combined with dark, decayed roots points to water-saturated soil that has favored pathogenic fungi causing root rot. Immediately improve drainage by lifting the bed or adding a 10 cm layer of coarse composted bark and perlite to the top 15 cm of soil, and irrigate only when the top 3 cm of soil is dry, giving one deep soaking of about 2.5 cm of water every 5–7 days rather than daily splashes. Remove and discard the worst-affected plant parts and leave 5 cm of space between crowns to boost airflow; apply a loose 3 cm straw mulch to keep surface moisture even but not soggy. Over the next week, inspect daily for (1) new white root tips emerging from the crown base, (2) any additional leaves turning soft brown rather than crisp, and (3) soil moisture at 5 cm depth staying slightly damp but never dripping when squeezed; adjust watering accordingly.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The crown tissue visible is a dark chocolate-brown with a water-soaked, almost gelatinous texture, and the outer cortex is peeling away in sheets, leaving only a small central core of firm white tissue; fine feeder roots are largely absent, and surrounding soil appears heavily stained and moist. These combined clues point to rot caused by prolonged saturation and poor aeration, most commonly from Phytophthora-type fungi thriving in waterlogged conditions. First, improve drainage immediately by lifting the plant onto a 15–20 cm high raised bed and blending 5 cm of coarse sand or grit into the top 10 cm of soil to speed water exit. Second, adjust irrigation: supply no more than 1–1.5 cm of water every 4–5 days, only when the top 3 cm of soil feels dry, and do so at dawn to maximize evaporation. Third, sanitize the crown by trimming away all soft brown tissue back to firm white with alcohol-wiped shears, then mulch lightly with 2 cm of clean straw to prevent soil splash while still allowing airflow. Over the next seven days, visually check each morning that (1) the soil at 5 cm depth is merely damp rather than wet, (2) no new brown, mushy zones appear on the crown surface, and (3) fresh white root tips begin to emerge at the crown edge, indicating recovery.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The visible crown section shows a dark reddish-brown ring of necrotic tissue surrounding a small core of still-white pith, the outer tissues appear water-soaked and collapsing, the adjacent potting mix is almost black and compacted, and dead leaf debris lies against the stem—together indicating prolonged saturation and decay. These symptoms are consistent with root rot caused by water-logged soil that favors fungi such as Phytophthora or Pythium. Immediately lift the plant or gently mound 3–4 cm of coarse compost and perlite under the crown to raise it above the wet zone, then irrigate only when the top 2.5 cm (1 in) of soil feels dry, applying no more than 500 ml (≈½ qt) per plant each time in the early morning. Remove and discard all mushy roots and any brown crown tissue with a sterile blade, and clear away leaf litter within a 10 cm (4 in) radius to improve airflow and reduce inoculum. Over the next week, press the crown lightly each day to confirm it stays firm, insert a wooden skewer 5 cm (2 in) into the soil to check that it comes out merely damp rather than wet, and inspect surrounding stems for any new brown water-soaked lesions or sour odor so corrective actions can be repeated promptly.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Microscopic view shows irregular watery-brown patches interlaced with pale blue-grey vascular strands, concentric dark rings surrounding several cortical cells, and localized cell collapse where tissue appears translucent rather than opaque. These patterns, together with the absence of healthy white fibrous texture, indicate advanced decay typical of water-saturated roots attacked by soil-borne oomycetes that thrive under prolonged moisture. Immediately reduce irrigation to no more than 2 cm (¾ in) depth every 4 days, ensuring the upper 2 cm of medium dries before the next watering, and raise the bed or container by 15–20 cm (6–8 in) to improve gravitational drainage. Loosen soil and mix in 25 % coarse compost or pine bark chips to boost aeration, and keep the crown zone free of mulch so air can circulate around stem bases. Over the next 7 days, visually inspect roots you uncover for a change from brown to light tan firmness, sniff for the disappearance of sour odor, and watch upper foliage for reduced midday wilting and renewed turgor as confirmation that oxygen balance is restored.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The lower tissue is dark brown-black, water-soaked, and mushy, with clear salmon-to-white spore masses clustered in crevices, and a sharp border between healthy and decayed areas, all indicating active fungal decay of the crown/root. These wet, discolored zones and visible spores point to prolonged saturation and poor aeration favoring a soil-borne rot pathogen. Immediately improve drainage by lifting the bed or container so water percolates through at least 5 cm (2 in) within 30 minutes after irrigation, and water only when the top 2 cm (¾ in) of soil feels dry, supplying 1–1.5 cm (½ in) of water early in the morning. Remove and discard any plants with more than 30 % crown discoloration; sterilize tools for 2 minutes in 10 % bleach before moving to healthy plants. Lay a 2 cm (¾ in) layer of coarse mulch or clean straw to reduce soil splash and keep crowns slightly elevated, and increase airflow by spacing plants at least 25 cm (10 in) apart. Over the next 7 days, inspect crowns daily for new salmon-colored spore cushions, press the crown gently to feel for further softening, and check that drainage water clears within 15 minutes of irrigation to verify improved soil porosity.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Microscopic view shows translucent root tissue turning honey-brown, linear dark streaks following the vascular core, several oval necrotic pockets, localized cortical collapse, and a coiled, transparent nematode-like organism embedded in the cortex. These combined clues point to water-saturated, poorly aerated conditions favoring oomycete infection and secondary nematode entry that accelerates rot. Immediately improve drainage by raising the strawberry bed 12–15 cm and blending 2–3 cm of coarse sand or fine bark into the top 10 cm of soil; irrigate only when the upper 3 cm of substrate is dry, supplying 2.5 cm of water via drip in early morning to keep roots moist but never waterlogged. Remove all visibly rotted plants, trim off slimy roots back to firm white tissue, and disinfect knives or shears in 70 °C water for one minute between cuts. Over the next seven days, probe soil daily at 5 cm depth to confirm it feels just slightly damp, lift one sentinel plant every other day to verify new roots are creamy white rather than brown, and use a 10× hand lens twice during the week to look for further nematode movement or fresh lesions along the exposed root surfaces.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The crown and main roots are dark brown to black and matted rather than light-colored and fibrous, many fine feeder roots are missing, leaves are wilted and papery with scorched edges, and undeveloped berries are shriveled and brown—all consistent with root tissue collapse. These symptoms point to excess moisture that has favored soil-borne fungi, suffocating roots and preventing water uptake. Elevate the bed or install a 15–20 cm (6–8 in) high raised row and incorporate coarse compost or 2 cm (¾ in) of sharp sand to improve drainage; thereafter irrigate only when the top 2.5 cm (1 in) of soil is dry, giving about 2 cm (¾ in) of water early in the morning. Remove and discard all dead plants plus any visibly blackened root debris, and keep mulch pulled back 5 cm (2 in) from crowns to enhance airflow. Over the next seven days, inspect daily for emergence of new white feeder roots at the crown base, note midday leaf firmness as an indicator of recovery, and check the soil surface each morning to confirm it is moist but not water-logged with no standing puddles.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Microscopy shows a sharply defined crimson lesion spreading from the epidermis into cortical tissue, collapsed and darkened cell walls along the vascular ring, diffuse crimson staining (arrow) indicating necrotic tissue, and adjacent pale-yellow cells that have lost turgor—all consistent with early rot localized but beginning to migrate inward. Such patchy, water-soaked discoloration and tissue breakdown point to roots kept chronically saturated, allowing opportunistic water-mold pathogens to colonize oxygen-starved cells. Immediately reduce irrigation to maintain only light moisture: supply 250 ml per plant every other day and verify that the top 5 cm (2 in) of soil dries slightly between waterings; raise the bed or pots on 3-5 cm (1–2 in) spacers to improve drainage; and add a 2 cm (¾ in) layer of coarse pine bark mulch to enhance aeration while preventing splashing. Trim away visibly brown, mushy roots with disinfected shears and discard debris to limit inoculum. Over the next 7 days, inspect the crown base each morning for fresh reddening or sliminess, probe soil at 5 cm depth with a finger to confirm it feels cool but not wet, and watch midday leaf stance for renewed turgor as an indicator that roots are regaining function.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The root system shows extensive blackening and water-soaked tissue, with many primary roots collapsed and covered in a slick, dark film; fine feeder roots are largely absent or shriveled, indicating loss of function. Crown tissue at the center is dark brown and necrotic, while adjacent stems display a soft, peeling cortex. Several attached leaves are completely desiccated and papery, confirming that vascular flow has already been interrupted. These combined symptoms point to root rot triggered by prolonged saturation and poor drainage, conditions that favor pathogens such as Phytophthora or Pythium. Immediately lift or replant into a raised bed or mound 15–20 cm high with 30 % coarse compost or sand mixed in, and irrigate only when the top 4 cm of soil is dry, supplying no more than 2 cm of water per session applied in early morning. Remove and discard all visibly affected plants and residues, and disinfect cutting tools in a 10 % bleach solution for one minute between plants to limit spread. Over the next seven days, visually verify that the soil surface is dry to a 4 cm depth before each watering, inspect newly forming root tips for a healthy white color rather than darkening, and check midday leaf posture—any renewed wilting or yellowing signals that drainage or moisture levels still need adjustment.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The exposed root mass shows uniform dark-brown discoloration, lack of healthy white feeder tips, and several strands are thin and hollow rather than plump. Root surfaces display flaking cortex and slight sliminess, and the fine roots snap easily when bent, evidencing advanced decay. These visible symptoms point to chronically waterlogged, poorly aerated soil that allows rot pathogens such as Pythium or Phytophthora to invade and kill cortical tissue. Correct by irrigating only when the top 2.5 cm (1 in) of soil is dry, applying roughly 2 cm (¾ in) of water in one early-morning session so moisture penetrates to about 10 cm (4 in) without puddling, and mixing 5 cm (2 in) of coarse compost or pine bark into the bed to boost drainage. Raise the planting row or container at least 15 cm (6 in) and keep mulch pulled 3 cm (1 in) clear of the crown to improve airflow and collar dryness. Over the next seven days, gently uncover one plant every two days to check for new firm white root tips, probe soil to 5 cm depth daily to confirm it dries slightly between waterings, and scan foliage each morning for fresh yellowing or wilting that would signal ongoing root decline.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The entire root mass shows widespread black-brown discoloration, fine feeder roots are missing or shriveled, outer cortical tissues are sloughing off in strands, several sections look water-soaked and slimy, and there are no bright white, turgid root tips anywhere. These visual cues point to prolonged saturation that encouraged soil-borne pathogens (typical Pythium/Phytophthora complex) to invade and decay the roots. Immediately lift affected plants and re-establish them on raised beds or ridges at least 15 cm (6 in) high with 5 cm (2 in) of coarse compost mixed in for faster drainage; irrigate only when the top 2 cm (¾ in) of soil feels dry, applying about 2.5 cm (1 in) of water in the early morning so crowns dry quickly. Remove and discard the worst plants, then disinfect tools with 10 % bleach solution to prevent spread; apply a 3 cm (1¼ in) layer of clean straw mulch to keep soil moisture even without waterlogging. Over the next seven days, inspect root crowns every other day for fresh white root tips emerging, probe soil at 5 cm depth with your finger to verify it is moist but never dripping, and look for any new foul odor or slimy exudate as an early warning sign to adjust watering or improve airflow further.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The exposed root mass is sparse and dark brown-black rather than creamy white, with many fine roots missing or visibly decayed. The crown tissue shows a dull reddish tint and slight collapse at the base, and the few remaining leaves appear dull with a slight downward wilt despite intact petioles. Surrounding straw mulch looks dry at the surface, hinting that rot started below where moisture lingers, concentrating decay at the lower crown and primary roots. These visual cues collectively point to water-saturated, poorly aerated soil fostering root-rot fungi. Raise the planting zone by 15–20 cm using a well-drained compost-sand mix, and irrigate only when the top 2.5 cm of soil is dry, delivering no more than 2 cm of water in the cool early morning. Remove this plant and any adjacent plant debris, then lightly fork the bed to a 10 cm depth to increase airflow around remaining roots. For the next seven days, insert a finger or moisture probe daily to 5 cm depth to ensure the soil feels just moist, not wet; inspect crowns each morning for fresh reddish softening or odor; and note leaf posture at midday—any new wilting or leaf dullness signals continuing rot progression that warrants further bed aeration.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The visible roots are uniformly dark brown-black, lacking the normal creamy color, with a water-soaked, slimy surface sheen; fine feeder roots are almost absent; several sections appear collapsed and stringy; and discoloration is continuous from tip to crown end. These clues indicate tissue death from prolonged saturation that favors rot pathogens and oxygen starvation. Immediately lift the affected plants, trim off all dark tissue back to firm white wood, then replant only in a raised bed or mound 15–20 cm high with well-drained mix; irrigate to a depth of 2.5 cm only when the top 3 cm of soil feels dry, never allowing standing water. Add a 2–3 cm coarse straw mulch to keep surface aerated and limit splashing, and space crowns at least 30 cm apart to boost airflow. Over the next 7 days, inspect excavated sample roots every other day for return of white, firm tips; press the soil at 3 cm depth daily to confirm it is just moist and not wet; and watch foliage bases for new red or brown streaking that would signal continuing infection.

Diagnosis: root_rot. I observe a sharply demarcated dark-brown to nearly black band encircling the outer cortex, a water-soaked sheen on the affected tissue, a healthy light-tan core that abruptly transitions to necrotic tissue, and fine feeder roots that appear shriveled and darkened; these clues collectively signal tissue decay progressing from the outside inward, typical of root-rot pathogens favored by excess moisture and low oxygen. The pattern and texture strongly suggest the roots have been sitting in saturated, poorly drained media that allowed water-molds such as Pythium or Phytophthora to colonize. Immediately improve drainage by raising the planting row or container 20 cm (8 in) with a coarse, well-aerated mix and limit irrigation to 2.5 cm (1 in) of water only when the top 3 cm (1 ¼ in) of soil feels dry; remove and discard the visibly rotten sections and any adjoining mushy debris, then top-dress with 5 cm (2 in) of clean straw mulch to keep surface moisture even without puddling. Increase airflow by spacing plants so that crowns sit at least 30 cm (12 in) apart and avoid evening watering to let foliage and crown dry before nightfall. Over the next seven days, inspect the crown-root junction daily for new darkening wider than 2 mm, probe soil 5 cm (2 in) deep to ensure it remains crumbly rather than clammy, and sniff for sour or sulfurous odors that would indicate ongoing anaerobic decay; if any of these signs worsen, remove the entire plant to prevent spread. Record root color changes, soil moisture readings, and odor observations at the same time each day to verify that corrective steps are halting progression.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The primary roots show patchy dark cinnamon-brown bands contrasting with lighter sections, several fine feeder roots are missing entirely, and the remaining laterals appear thin, brittle and slightly shriveled; a few tips exhibit blackened necrosis, and the discoloration is concentrated closest to branch points rather than uniformly along the length. These visual cues indicate tissue collapse typical of water-saturated, oxygen-poor conditions that favor Phytophthora/Pythium attack. Immediately lower watering to no more than 2.5 cm (1 in) of total irrigation per application, spaced every 5 days, and raise the planting row or container base by at least 15 cm (6 in) with a coarse bark-sand mix to hasten drainage. Add a 3 cm (1.2 in) layer of loose straw mulch to keep surface moisture even while allowing air exchange, and remove any dead plant debris within 30 cm (12 in) of the crown to reduce inoculum. Over the next 7 days, gently expose a small section of crown roots every other day to verify emergence of firm, white feeder roots, insert a finger or moisture probe to 5 cm (2 in) depth to confirm the soil feels damp but not wet, and inspect the root collar daily for any new darkening or soft, water-soaked tissue that would signal continuing rot progression.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Dark reddish-brown streaks run longitudinally along otherwise pale root tissue, the lesions are water-soaked and glassy, some segments show black specks of decayed debris, and discoloration is patchy yet concentrated on the lower half of the shown roots. These visual patterns suggest tissue collapse and cell wall breakdown consistent with excessive moisture and poor oxygen around the crown zone. Saturated soil that remained above field capacity for extended periods is the most likely catalyst for opportunistic fungi that cause root rot. Immediately improve drainage by lifting the strawberry bed 10–15 cm with a well-draining mix (50 % loam, 30 % coarse sand, 20 % compost) and irrigate only when the top 2.5 cm of soil is dry, applying no more than 2.5 cm of water evenly over the bed every four days. Remove and discard visibly blackened roots, then lay a 3 cm layer of clean straw mulch to regulate surface moisture and airflow. Over the next seven days, inspect roots at two random plants each morning for fresh brown streaks or mucilaginous patches, probe the soil after watering to confirm it drains within 30 minutes, and watch for wilted foliage that fails to recover by evening as an early sign that rot is still progressing.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The fine feeder roots are shriveled and orange-brown internally while the outer cortex has turned charcoal-grey and is sloughing off, several roots show black, water-soaked cracks along their length, and no healthy white root tips are visible. This combination of internal browning, surface necrosis, and loss of turgor indicates tissue collapse consistent with water-logged, oxygen-poor conditions that favor root-rot pathogens. Immediately lift the bed or pot so the crown sits at least 3 cm above surrounding soil, irrigate only when the top 3 cm of soil is dry, and apply no more than 2.5 cm of water in a single event to keep the root zone moist but aerated. Incorporate 5–7 cm of coarse composted bark or straw mulch around (not on) the crown to improve drainage and maintain an even surface moisture, and prune away and discard all visibly blackened roots with sterile scissors to reduce inoculum. Over the next seven days, probe the soil daily to 5 cm depth to ensure it remains crumbly, inspect emerging root tips for a firm white color rather than tan or grey, and sniff the crown area every other day for any sour or sulfur odor that would signal continuing rot. If any newly formed roots begin to darken or feel mushy, withhold watering an extra day and increase airflow by spacing plants at least 25 cm apart.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The root system on the left is notably sparse, with many primary roots blackened and brittle, while the comparison plant on the right shows dense, light-tan fibrous roots; the dark roots also appear water-soaked and lack fine feeder hairs, and the crown tissue at the top of the left sample is shrunken. Such generalized darkening and loss of root mass are consistent with roots suffocating in poorly drained, saturated soil, which encourages soil-borne rot organisms. Immediately improve drainage by raising the bed at least 20 cm and irrigating only when the top 3 cm of soil is dry, applying no more than 2.5 cm of water per session in the early morning so excess can drain. Incorporate 5 cm of coarse compost or sand into the upper 15 cm of soil and apply a 3 cm straw mulch to moderate moisture swings; discard the affected plants and sanitize tools with 10 % bleach for one minute before re-use. Over the next seven days, lift a small edge plant every two days to confirm new white root tips are forming, probe soil at 5 cm depth for a moist-but-not-wet feel, and check crowns daily for firmness and absence of sour odor to verify conditions are no longer favoring rot.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Multiple lower leaves display large, irregular reddish-brown blotches and dry, papery margins, several petioles are shriveled and dark, and the exposed roots appear thin, blackened, and stringy rather than firm and white—indicating decay that begins below the crown and moves upward. These discolorations clustered on the oldest foliage, together with the mushy, discolored root mass, are consistent with water-saturated soil enabling opportunistic rot-causing fungi. Improve drainage immediately by lifting plants onto 15–20 cm-high ridges or mounded rows and incorporating coarse compost or sand to at least 10 cm depth; irrigate only when the top 5 cm of soil is dry, aiming for 2–3 cm of water applied in early morning once every 4–5 days instead of frequent light sprinkling. Remove and discard all visibly rotted roots and necrotic leaves, sterilizing tools with 70 % alcohol between plants, and add a 2 cm layer of clean straw mulch to keep crowns out of standing water. Over the next 7 days, check daily for: 1) new root tips turning cream-white and firm rather than dark and slimy, 2) emergence of fresh green leaflets without wilting within 24 h of sunrise, and 3) absence of new brown water-soaked lesions spreading along petioles. If any of these indicators regress, reassess soil moisture and airflow before considering further intervention.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Visible clues include: (1) crowns and adjacent root collars are dark brown-to-black and water-soaked, (2) most roots are sparse, brittle and lack healthy white tips, (3) lower leaves are wilted with V-shaped necrosis advancing from the margin, (4) several blades show yellow halos around brown patches, and (5) petiole bases display a dull, shriveled texture compared with upper green tissue. Such crown-centered decay combined with leaf wilt strongly points to soil saturation that favors Phytophthora–induced root and crown rot. Corrective actions: mound rows or pots so crowns sit at least 15 cm above the surrounding soil, and irrigate only when the top 2–3 cm of soil feels dry, applying roughly 1 L of water per plant early in the morning; remove all plants that show more than 50 % crown blackening and discard them off-site, sterilizing tools for 60 seconds in 10 % bleach; and lay a 2 cm coarse straw mulch strip between rows (not touching crowns) to improve surface drainage and airflow. For the next 7 days, check daily for: continued midday wilting versus regained leaf rigidity, any fresh dark streaking visible when gently scraping 0.5 cm of crown tissue, and the appearance of new white feeder roots when you loosen the soil to a 3 cm depth around sample plants. Document changes with photos and measurements of wilted leaf counts to verify stabilization or spread.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The root mass shows widespread dark brown-to-black discoloration, many fine feeder roots are missing or shriveled, surviving roots are limp rather than crisp, the crown base is water-soaked and slightly collapsed, and the foliage above is stunted with pale, wilting leaflets. Such widespread root necrosis, combined with a softened crown, is most consistent with rot triggered by chronically saturated soil that favors soil-borne fungi. Immediately lift plants onto 20 cm-high raised ridges or benches, irrigate only when the top 3 cm of soil is dry, and limit each watering to about 2.5 cm depth to restore aeration; add 5 cm of coarse composted bark around—but not against—the crown to improve drainage and airflow. Remove and discard the darkest, mushiest roots with sterile scissors and clear any standing water channels so excess rain drains within 30 minutes. Over the next 7 days visually check that new root tips appear white rather than brown, confirm the soil surface dries to the first knuckle (≈4 cm) before each irrigation, and inspect leaves daily for regained turgor and absence of further yellowing; if any new blackening or foul odor is seen at the crown, reassess drainage and root condition immediately.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Multiple plants show dull yellow to brown, wilted lower leaves and collapsed petioles, dark water-soaked roots with few fine rootlets, an orange-brown necrotic ring in the crown cross-section, and general stunting compared with adjacent foliage, all originating from the root zone upward. These combined clues point to root decay triggered by chronically saturated substrate that encourages fungi such as Phytophthora or Pythium. Improve drainage immediately by raising the bed 10–15 cm or blending in roughly 20 % coarse sand, and ensure every pot or trough clears free water within 30 s of irrigation. Apply water only in early morning, supplying about 2.5 cm (1 in) total per week and waiting until the top 2–3 cm of soil is dry before the next cycle; avoid puddling under benches. Enhance airflow by spacing plants 25–30 cm apart, removing all dead foliage, and adding a loose 2 cm straw mulch layer to reduce splash without trapping moisture. For the next 7 days, probe moisture daily at 5 cm depth to confirm it is damp not waterlogged, inspect crowns for any expansion of brown tissue wider than 2 mm, and record the daily count of wilted leaves so a downward trend signals recovery.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Multiple lower leaves exhibit dull reddish-brown blotches and marginal necrosis, scattered patches of foliage are collapsing while adjacent crowns stay green, several flowers sit above noticeably stunted, sparse canopies, and the overall stand shows uneven vigor with open gaps in the straw mulch. Such patchy wilt and discoloration, especially beginning on older leaves and intensifying toward the crown, typically signals water-logged soil that has allowed soil-borne fungi to attack the roots. Improve drainage by raising the bed or adding a 15 cm (6 in) layer of well-drained composted mix around the crowns and irrigate only when the top 5 cm (2 in) of soil is dry, delivering about 2.5 cm (1 in) of water every 3–4 days rather than daily. Remove and discard all visibly browned leaves and any collapsed plants, cutting them off at crown level with disinfected shears, and replenish straw mulch to an even 3 cm (1.2 in) depth to reduce surface splash. Over the next week, visually check each morning for newly wilted leaves or browning spreading up the petiole, probe soil moisture at 5 cm depth to keep it merely moist rather than wet, and sniff crowns for any sour odor indicating further rot. If browning expands or moisture remains high despite adjustments, consider additional aeration or re-planting in a different, better-drained location.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The excavated roots show (1) dark brown to nearly black streaks running length-wise through the vascular core, (2) patchy soft, water-soaked tissues that have lost their natural white firmness, (3) a sharp transition between pale tan healthy zones and necrotic bands, and (4) slight surface sloughing at multiple points rather than a clean, fibrous exterior. These clues collectively indicate tissue death caused by prolonged saturation that favors soil-borne rot pathogens and oxygen starvation. Immediately improve drainage by raising the planting bed 15–20 cm and incorporating 5 cm of coarse composted bark to keep the root zone airy; irrigate only when the top 3 cm of soil is dry, delivering roughly 2 cm of water in the early morning so the surface dries by noon. Pull away any existing mulch from the crown by 5 cm and thin surrounding foliage to create a 20 cm wide airflow gap, reducing humidity at soil level. Over the next 7 days, visually check roots from one sacrificed plant every other day for spreading discoloration beyond 2 cm, watch for standing water lasting more than 4 hours after irrigation or rain, and note any new wilted leaves that fail to recover by evening as early warnings of continuing rot activity.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Exposed roots are tan to dark-brown with patchy blackened bands and missing fine feeder hairs, several primary roots appear hollow or mushy, the crown tissue is discolored, and surrounding leaves are shriveled and papery brown. These visual clues indicate prolonged saturation and poor aeration that encourage soil-borne fungi, resulting in root tissue collapse and decay. Raise the planting area or install a 15–20 cm high mound to improve drainage, and water only when the upper 5 cm of soil is dry, delivering about 2.5 cm of water in one early-morning session each week rather than frequent light sprinklings. Work in 3–5 cm of coarse compost or sand around the root zone to increase porosity, and spread a 3 cm layer of clean straw mulch to keep soil surface aerated while limiting future splash. Remove and discard all visibly rotted roots and dead leaves, disinfecting tools between plants to prevent spread. Over the next 7 days, inspect the crown daily for firmness rather than softness, check that new irrigation leaves the soil moist but not dripping when squeezed, and look for emergence of fresh white feeder roots or any renewed browning along root tips to gauge recovery.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Multiple roots in panels A, C and E exhibit extensive dark brown to black discoloration, loss of cortical tissue and a water-soaked sheen, while the contrasting samples in B and D remain pale tan and fibrous; panel C shows a sharp transition from white feeder roots to black necrotic strands, and panel F reveals circular, thick-walled structures embedded in collapsed root cells. These visual cues indicate tissue death progressing from the exterior inward, consistent with pathogen activity promoted by saturated, poorly-aerated media. Improve drainage by raising beds 20 cm and incorporating 5 cm of coarse sand or pine bark, and irrigate only when the top 4 cm of soil is dry, delivering 2 cm of water early morning no more than twice weekly. Pull back mulch from the crown by 5 cm to enhance airflow, and sterilize cutting tools with 70 % alcohol for 30 s before moving between plants to limit spread. Over the next seven days, lift one sentinel plant every two days to inspect for fresh white root tips versus further browning, probe soil with a moisture meter to verify readings stay below 35 % volumetric water content, and note any sour odor or wilting foliage that would signal advancing rot requiring immediate drainage correction.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The entire root mass appears dark brown-to-black rather than creamy white, many strands look water-soaked and slimy, the cortex is sloughing off to reveal fragile inner threads, and the crown tissue at the top shows an orange-brown discoloration that stops abruptly at the healthy stem above. These visual clues point to roots suffocating in saturated, poorly drained substrate, allowing opportunistic water-mold fungi to invade and cause rot. Improve drainage immediately by lifting plants onto a 15 cm (6 in) high, 25 cm (10 in) wide raised ridge or by incorporating coarse sand or composted bark at 30 % by volume into the top 20 cm (8 in) of soil; thereafter irrigate only when the upper 5 cm (2 in) feels dry, delivering 1.5 cm (0.6 in) of water in the early morning so foliage dries quickly. Remove and discard all visibly rotted roots, then mulch around the crowns with a 3 cm (1 in) layer of clean straw to moderate moisture fluctuations and keep soil off the plants. Over the next 7 days, check daily for: 1) emergence of fresh white feeder roots near the crown, 2) any new darkening or softening spreading upward more than 0.5 cm (0.2 in), and 3) soil moisture staying below field capacity when a finger inserted 5 cm (2 in) feels only slightly damp, adjusting irrigation accordingly.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The root mass shows uniform light-to-dark cinnamon browning instead of healthy white, several black necrotic patches clustered near the crown, loss of fine feeder roots leaving stringy cores, and a soft, water-soaked texture visible where the cortex has sloughed off. Such widespread discoloration and tissue collapse are typical of roots kept chronically wet, favoring soil-borne fungi that cause rot. Immediately improve drainage by raising the bed 15–20 cm and incorporating 5 cm of coarse compost or perlite through the top 20 cm of soil; water only when the top 5 cm of soil is dry, delivering 1 cm of water in the early morning no more than twice a week. Remove the most affected plants and discard the debris away from the plot to reduce inoculum, and keep a 5 cm layer of clean straw mulch to prevent soil splash while still allowing airflow around the crown. Over the next 7 days visibly check that new root tips emerging near the crown are creamy white, confirm soil remains crumbly rather than sticky at a 5 cm fingertip test, and watch for any new black lesions or foul odor that would signal persistent saturation.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The majority of fibrous roots are dark brown to almost black, only a few strands remain pale beige, and several segments look water-soaked and collapsed, with outer tissues sloughing off and a clear boundary of discoloration extending toward the crown, making the root mass sparse compared with the 1 cm scale bar. These clues indicate advanced root rot triggered by chronic saturation and poor aeration, conditions that favor soil-borne pathogens such as Phytophthora or Pythium. Immediately improve drainage by transplanting or mounding the plant 10 cm (4 in) higher than surrounding grade and blending 30 % coarse compost or perlite into the backfill; thereafter irrigate only when the upper 5 cm (2 in) of soil is dry, supplying about 2 cm (¾ in) of water in the early morning so excess can escape. Trim away all black, mushy roots with sterilized shears and dispose of them, then apply a 2 cm (¾ in) layer of clean straw mulch to stabilize moisture without sealing the surface. For the next seven days, inspect daily for new firm white root tips near the crown, sniff the root zone for sour odors when you probe 5 cm deep, and watch for any fresh brown exudate around cut surfaces. If newly formed roots brown within 48 h, reduce watering volume by 25 % and increase soil aeration further by gently loosening the top 3 cm of soil around the crown.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The entire fibrous root mass is uniformly orange-brown rather than creamy white, fine feeder roots are largely missing, and the remaining stubs appear shriveled and stringy; outer cortical tissue is sloughing off, exposing darker stele; several root tips show blackened necrosis; and the affected section is no more than 5 cm long yet already brittle and dehydrated. These clues point to chronic waterlogging that has favored soil-borne rot organisms such as Phytophthora or Pythium, leading to loss of healthy tissue and collapse of feeder roots. Immediately improve drainage by raising the strawberry bed 15–20 cm and amending with 30 % coarse compost or perlite to increase porosity; irrigate only when the top 4 cm of soil is dry, applying 2–3 cm of water in one early-morning session, then allow the bed to drain fully; and remove and discard all visibly affected plants, sanitizing tools for 1 minute in a 10 % bleach solution before reuse. Over the next 7 days, probe soil at 5 cm depth to confirm it feels moist but never saturated, inspect newly emerging roots for bright white tips, and check base of crowns daily for any fresh browning or foul odor indicating persistent infection.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The harvested crown shows uniformly dark brown-black discoloration instead of healthy cream, the outer cortex is slimy and easily peels, fine feeder roots are largely absent or shriveled, the central core is water-soaked with a slight orange tinge, and the decay extends from crown to tip rather than being localized. Such widespread darkening and tissue collapse point to water-saturated conditions that favored soil-borne pathogens attacking oxygen-starved roots. Immediately lift plants onto a mound or raised bed at least 15 cm high, supply only 2–3 cm of water every 5 days and only when the top 3 cm of soil feels dry, and incorporate 4 cm of coarse compost or pine-bark mulch to improve drainage and airflow around crowns. Remove and discard all obviously rotted plants and sterilize cutting tools for 30 seconds in 10 % bleach before touching healthy roots. Over the next 7 days, visually check daily for new white root tips emerging at the crown, probe soil 5 cm deep to ensure it is moist but never soggy, and note any fresh areas of browning or mushy odor so action can be adjusted promptly.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Visible clues include (1) uniform cinnamon-orange discoloration of the sliced crown core, (2) dark brown to black necrotic tissue outlining the crown edges, (3) sparse, wiry roots with black lesions and missing root hairs, (4) shriveled, darkened petiole bases at the crown top, and (5) some fine roots coated with adherent gray soil indicating poor vitality. These colour and texture changes point to prolonged soil saturation that deprived roots of oxygen and enabled soil-borne fungi such as Phytophthora or Pythium to colonize the crown. Correct conditions by raising the planting zone 8–10 cm using a 50 % compost-50 % coarse sand blend and irrigate only when the top 3 cm surface is dry, applying about 1 L (≈0.25 gal) per plant in the early morning so water penetrates no deeper than 2 cm and drains within 4 hours. Improve airflow by spacing plants 30 cm apart and adding a 3 cm layer of clean straw mulch to reduce splash and evaporate excess moisture; promptly remove and discard the symptomatic plant along with the top 5 cm of soil and sanitize tools for 60 seconds in 10 % bleach. For the next 7 days, check each morning for sudden leaf wilt despite cool temperatures, slice one suspect crown every two days looking for any return of cinnamon bands, and press soil at 5 cm depth—if it clings in a slick ball, delay watering until it crumbles.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Multiple dark, nearly circular lesions 10–15 µm across are embedded in the cortex, their edges sharply defined and surrounded by a gray-black halo, indicating localized tissue necrosis; the surrounding parenchyma shows a mottled charcoal tone rather than the translucent white expected in healthy root cells; cell walls appear collapsed and poorly delineated, suggesting loss of structural integrity; intercellular spaces are filled with fine, thread-like strands consistent with fungal hyphae; overall contrast between intact and degraded zones points to progressive decay starting internally and spreading outward. These clues strongly imply water-favored fungal infection (most commonly Phytophthora/Pythium) attacking saturated, oxygen-starved roots. Immediately lower irrigation frequency so that only when the top 2 cm (¾ in) of soil feels dry should 1–1.5 cm (⅜–⅝ in) of water be applied; create a 5 cm (2 in) raised ridge around each crown to improve drainage and prevent standing water; spread a 2 cm (¾ in) coarse wood-chip mulch to reduce splash and enhance airflow at the soil surface. Over the next 7 days, visually inspect root sections for any new dark rings larger than 20 µm, check whether previously blackened tissue lightens toward pale cream (sign of recovery), and gently tug crowns every other day to confirm increased root anchorage rather than the current soft pull-out associated with rot.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Visible evidence includes dark-brown to black cortical tissue on the root collars, missing or thread-thin feeder roots, orange-tan but water-soaked pith in the crown cross-sections, and clumped, mud-stained root masses indicating prolonged saturation. The pattern suggests chronic waterlogging that fostered soil-borne fungi, leading to decay of fine roots and internal crown discoloration. Immediately improve drainage by raising the bed or container height 20 cm and mixing in 25 % coarse compost or perlite through the top 15 cm of soil; then irrigate only when the upper 5 cm of soil is dry, delivering 2.5 cm of water in one deep application every 4 days instead of daily light sprinkles. Remove and discard all obviously rotten plants and trim off any soft, black roots, disinfecting tools with 10 % bleach for 1 minute between plants. Apply a 3 cm layer of straw or pine-needle mulch to keep surface moisture even while allowing air flow, and maintain 30 cm spacing between crowns to speed surface drying. Over the next 7 days, visually check for emergence of new white root tips at the crown bases, monitor soil moisture at 5 cm depth with a finger or moisture probe to ensure it reaches a barely damp feel before re-watering, and inspect remaining crowns daily for any fresh darkening or foul odor that would signal ongoing rot.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Visible clues include (1) a sparse, wiry root mass with very few white feeder roots, (2) several primary roots turning dark brown and brittle, (3) crown tissue showing patchy caramel-brown discoloration rather than uniform creamy white, (4) slight collapse and shriveling at the crown-root junction, and (5) no visible root hairs on the bottom 4–5 cm of the plant. This combination points to water-saturated soil that favored soil-borne fungi and deprived roots of oxygen, leading to root rot. Immediately transplant survivors into a raised bed or container at least 15 cm (6 in) high with a well-drained mix containing 30 % coarse compost and 20 % perlite; irrigate to a depth of 5 cm (2 in) only when the top 3 cm (1 in) of soil is dry, and ensure drainage holes remain clear. Space plants 30 cm (12 in) apart and mulch with a 2 cm (¾ in) layer of clean straw to reduce splash without trapping excess moisture. Over the next 7 days, visually check that the upper 3 cm of soil dries within 48 h after watering, confirm new white root tips are visible through the drainage holes or at the crown base, and watch for any fresh crown softening or dark streaks; absence of these signs indicates recovery.

Diagnosis: root_rot. I observe a dark brown–black necrotic band encircling the cut crown core, most primary roots are thin and uniformly dark rather than creamy white, fine feeder roots are largely missing, the crown base appears water-soaked and softened, and loose soil particles cling to decomposing tissue—five clues indicating advanced rot. These symptoms point to prolonged saturation and poor drainage that favor anaerobic pathogens such as Phytophthora or Pythium attacking the root system. Raise the planting bed at least 15 cm (6 in) and blend 5 cm (2 in) of coarse composted bark through the top 20 cm (8 in) to improve porosity and runoff; switch to deep, infrequent irrigation by applying 2.5 cm (1 in) of water once every 5 days only after the top 5 cm (2 in) of soil feels dry; and remove infected plants promptly, sanitizing cutting tools for 2 minutes in a 10 % bleach solution to prevent spread. For the next 7 days, check soil moisture at 5 cm depth each morning before watering, inspect crowns daily for any new dark streaks or amber exudate, and gently expose a few root tips every other day to verify the emergence of firm, white roots rather than continued browning.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The fine feeder roots are largely absent and replaced by dark-brown, brittle strands, the main roots show patchy blackening and slight mushiness, and the outer cortex is peeling away, exposing fiber-like cores; additionally, the crown’s core has a water-soaked orange ring bordered by a darker rim and the healthy white tissue is limited to a narrow central zone. These symptoms together point to rot caused by prolonged soil saturation and limited oxygen, favouring soil-borne fungi such as Phytophthora or Pythium. Immediately lift plants onto a bed or ridge at least 20 cm high, incorporate 5 cm of coarse compost or pine bark into the top 15 cm of soil to improve drainage, and restrict irrigation to when the top 5 cm of soil is dry, delivering no more than 2 cm of water in a single application. Maintain open canopy airflow by spacing plants 30 cm apart and remove any obviously decayed roots with sanitized snips to reduce inoculum. Over the next seven days, visually check daily for development of fresh white root tips at the crown base, squeeze the crown to confirm it remains firm not spongy, and inspect soil surface each morning to ensure it is only slightly moist and never puddled.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The entire root mass shows dark brown to nearly black strands instead of healthy white fibres, several roots are hollow with the cortex already sloughed, the crown tissue is caramel-orange with a water-soaked margin, and fine feeder roots are largely absent, all concentrated around what should be the central root zone. This pattern of discoloration, cortical decay and missing fine roots indicates prolonged saturation that favours rot-causing fungi such as Phytophthora or Pythium. Lift and replant in a raised bed 15–20 cm high and at least 30 cm wide to improve drainage, irrigating only when the top 3 cm of soil is dry and then applying no more than 2 cm of water via drip in the early morning; discard all obviously infected plants and sanitize pruners with 70 % alcohol between cuts. Mulch with a 2-cm layer of clean straw to reduce splashing and maintain even but not soggy moisture, and ensure 25 cm of plant spacing for airflow around crowns. Over the next 7 days, probe the soil each morning to 3 cm depth and verify it is only lightly damp, inspect the crown base for any fresh reddish-brown streaking or soft spots, and gently expose a few roots every other day to confirm new growth is white, firm and turgid rather than tan or mushy.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The central crown tissue shows a wet-looking orange-brown discoloration, several primary roots are dark and brittle rather than cream-white, fine feeder roots are largely missing, and a few remaining roots exhibit shrivelling with a water-soaked sheen. Such patchy browning that begins at the crown and moves outward typically indicates decay from excess moisture and poor aeration allowing rot-pathogens to colonize. Immediately improve drainage by raising the planting row 15–20 cm and incorporating 4 cm of coarse compost and perlite to loosen soil; water no more than 2.5 cm every 4–5 days, ensuring the top 5 cm dries slightly between irrigations; apply a 2 cm straw mulch layer to keep surface moist but crown dry. Increase airflow by spacing plants 30 cm apart and removing any dead foliage touching the soil to discourage further pathogen spread. Over the next 7 days, lift one sample plant every two days to check that new root tips appear white and firm, probe soil at 10 cm depth each morning aiming for crumbly not soggy consistency, and inspect the crown base daily for any fresh darkening or soft, sour-smelling tissue so corrective action can be taken promptly.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The crown cores are chocolate-brown and water-soaked, the fine roots are sparse, dark and stringy instead of plump and white, and several cortical layers have sloughed away leaving thin, woody strands; additionally, a wet sheen is visible on the cut surfaces and no healthy feeder roots remain. These patterns indicate prolonged saturation and limited oxygen around the root zone, favouring soil-borne pathogens that cause crown and root rot. Immediately lift the plant into a raised bed or pot with a 15-20 cm deep mix of 60 % coarse sand and 40 % composted bark to improve drainage, and irrigate only when the top 2.5 cm of medium is dry, applying about 1.5–2 cm of water in the early morning so the root zone dries by nightfall. Remove and discard all visibly brown or mushy roots, then replant so the crown sits 1 cm above the soil line, and place a 2 cm layer of clean straw mulch around (not touching) the crown to moderate moisture swings. Over the next 7 days, inspect daily for new white root tips emerging at the container edge, press the crown gently to confirm it is firm rather than spongy, and use a moisture probe or finger to keep soil at a moderate (40–50 %) moisture level, adjusting watering if the reading at 5 cm depth stays above this range. If any new brown lesions creep upward on the crown or a sour odor returns, further root removal or discarding the plant will be required.

Diagnosis: root_rot. Cross-sectioned crowns display a dark reddish-brown core bordered by soft yellow exudate, the surrounding root cortex is blackened and sloughing, and there are virtually no white feeder roots, while in the bed a distinct patch of plants shows complete leaf desiccation contrasted against adjacent healthy green foliage. These clustered, water-soaked lesions and rapid plant collapse point to root/crown rot driven by prolonged soil saturation that favors soilborne pathogens. Immediately remove the visibly dead clump plus 20 cm of adjoining soil and plant material, discard off-site, and improve drainage by lifting the bed with an additional 7–10 cm of well-draining composted mix. Irrigate only in the early morning every 3–4 days, delivering 1.5 cm of water each time and allowing the top 5 cm of soil to dry before the next cycle; avoid standing water around crowns. Spread a 2 cm layer of coarse straw mulch to reduce surface compaction and splash dispersal, and keep foliage spacing at least 15 cm between crowns to enhance airflow. Over the next seven days, probe soil 5 cm deep daily to confirm it feels barely moist, inspect crown bases for any new dark discoloration or softness, and watch mid-day leaf turgor—any fresh wilting or yellow ooze indicates further action is needed.

Diagnosis: root_rot. The affected strawberry shows black, stringy, shriveled roots compared with the adjacent plant’s thick, creamy-white roots, and its leaves are wilted with brown, dry margins while the healthier plant remains green and turgid. Both pots sit in water-filled saucers and the soil surface looks constantly saturated, pointing to prolonged waterlogging that deprives roots of oxygen and invites rot-causing fungi. Remove both pots from the saucers, clear the drainage holes, and repot the sick plant into a mix of 2 parts peat-based compost and 1 part coarse perlite, trimming off all dark roots and keeping the crown no deeper than 1 cm below the surface. Water only when the top 2.5 cm (1 in) of medium is dry, giving about 180 ml (6 fl oz) per 12 cm pot and letting excess drain fully; discard any runoff instead of letting it collect. Space the plants at least 15 cm (6 in) apart and lay a 1 cm (0.4 in) layer of clean straw mulch to keep surface moisture even while promoting airflow. Over the next 7 days, confirm daily that no water stands in the trays, that the upper 2 cm of mix dries within 48 h after each irrigation, and that new central leaves emerge firm and green without additional browning or collapse.
